The complainant later submitted an affidavit expressing no objection to anticipatory bail for the in-laws.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail could be granted in a case involving dowry-related suicide and charges under the Atrocities Act when prima facie evidence was lacking and the complainant withdrew objection.
judgment_reason: The court noted the complainant’s affidavit, lack of prima facie evidence under the Atrocities Act, appellant no. 2’s old age and illness, and appellant no. 1’s separate residence. It held custodial interrogation unnecessary and granted anticipatory bail with conditions.
summary: Gujarat High Court granted anticipatory bail to Kaminiben and another in a dowry-related suicide case, citing lack of prima facie case and complainant's retraction.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Anticipatory bail may be granted in Atrocities Act cases if no prima facie case is made out', 'Affidavit of complainant retracting allegations can influence bail decision', 'Custodial interrogation not mandatory in all dowry death cases']

case_title: Santosh Rawat vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 1 year and 8 months of custody; court found over-implication, no prior complaints, and absence of cruelty evidence before death.
facts: Santosh Rawat was charged under Sections 498A and 304B IPC after his wife died by hanging within three years of marriage. Allegations included dowry demands of ₹5 lakh. No prior complaints were made by the deceased or her family. After investigation, charges were dropped against other family members and only Santosh was charge-sheeted. He was in custody since September 2020 and no witnesses had been examined by the trial court.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused husband is the only person charge-sheeted for a dowry death, with no prior complaint or cruelty evidence, and prolonged pre-trial detention.
judgment_reason: The court found merit in the claim of over-implication and noted the absence of prior complaints or evidence of cruelty. Considering prolonged custody and no progress in trial, bail was granted under conditions.
summary: Allahabad High Court granted bail to Santosh Rawat in a dowry death case, citing over-implication, absence of prior complaints, and prolonged pre-trial detention.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration without trial progress may justify bail', 'Bail is the rule, jail is the exception (State of Rajasthan v. Balchand)', 'Prima facie case and nature of allegations are relevant for bail decisions']

case_title: Balram Singh vs State Of Himachal Pradesh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after noting lack of suicide note, absence of direct allegations from key witnesses, and release of co-accused on bail.
facts: Balram Singh was arrested following the death of his wife Pinki Devi, who was found hanging from a tree. Initially, the father and grandfather of the deceased did not accuse anyone, but later, her mother filed a complaint alleging that the deceased was harassed for dowry. Co-accused were already granted bail. No prior complaints or suicide note existed, and the deceased had voluntarily returned to the matrimonial home.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted when initial witnesses gave no allegations, no suicide note exists, and co-accused have been granted bail in a dowry death case.
judgment_reason: The Court emphasized the presumption of innocence, noted absence of prior complaints or suicide note, inconsistencies in family statements, and that nothing remained to be recovered from the accused. It concluded prolonged incarceration was unjustified.
summary: Himachal Pradesh High Court granted bail to Balram Singh in a dowry death case, citing absence of a suicide note, non-incriminating initial witness statements, and co-accused already on bail.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Presumption of innocence under Article 21 of the Constitution', 'Bail is the rule, jail is the exception', 'Bail may be granted when no direct evidence or recovery is pending']

case_title: State vs Mohd. Danish & Anr
accused_name: Mohd. Danish and Sabbir Mohd. @ Sabbu
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Suo moto proceedings for bail cancellation dropped; court found no misuse of bail and justified differential treatment from co-accused with serious criminal antecedents.
facts: The High Court took suo moto cognizance to examine whether bail granted to Mohd. Danish and Sabbir Mohd. @ Sabbu should be cancelled, noting they were granted bail while co-accused Saddam Khan’s bail was rejected. Saddam Khan had serious criminal antecedents involving dacoity and robbery, unlike the present respondents. The court found no allegation of misuse of bail by the respondents.
legal_issues: Whether bail granted to accused without criminal antecedents should be cancelled when a co-accused with serious prior offences was denied bail.
judgment_reason: The court upheld the trial court’s reasoning, emphasizing the relevance of criminal history in bail matters. Since there was no allegation of misuse of bail by the respondents, the court declined to cancel their bail.
summary: Rajasthan High Court declined to cancel bail of Mohd. Danish and co-accused, finding no misuse of bail and distinguishing them from a co-accused with serious prior offences.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Criminal antecedents are material while considering bail applications', 'Suo moto cancellation of bail requires justification and evidence of misuse']

case_title: Rajinder Singh @ Anil Kumar vs State Of H.P
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to strong prima facie case, criminal antecedents, and risk of absconding
facts: Rajinder Singh alias Anil Kumar was accused of drugging and rendering unconscious three women and five men at Hotel Himani, Solan, and stealing their mobile phones and ATM cards. He had used a fake Aadhaar card and fled the scene. He was later arrested in a similar case in Meerut. CCTV footage, room keys, and toxicology reports substantiated his involvement.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused has criminal antecedents, absconded after the crime, and is accused of repeated similar offences involving fraud and administering intoxicants.
judgment_reason: The Court cited multiple precedents affirming the importance of antecedents, seriousness of the crime, and societal impact. It found that the petitioner had committed similar crimes in the past, absconded after the incident, and possessed strong incriminating material linking him to the offence. Bail was therefore denied.
summary: Himachal Pradesh High Court denied regular bail to Rajinder Singh citing criminal history, serious charges of drugging and fraud, and flight risk.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Criminal antecedents are a critical factor in bail decisions', 'Absconding after crime weighs against bail', 'Prima facie evidence and risk to society must be weighed over individual liberty']

case_title: Abhishek Balu Sasane @ Abhishek Manoj vs The State Of Maharashtra
accused_name: Abhishek Balu Sasane @ Abhishek Manoj Patil
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 2 years in custody; court noted absence of test identification parade, incomplete CCTV evidence, and trial delay.
facts: On 6 March 2022, the complainant and a friend were diverted by an auto-rickshaw driven by the accused to a different location in Pune, where two rear passengers threatened them with a knife and robbed them of mobile phones, cash, and PhonePe transfers. The applicant was arrested on 9 March 2022 and charged with armed robbery under IPC and Arms Act provisions. He had prior cases, but was acquitted or granted bail in some.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged pre-trial custody and procedural lapses like lack of test identification and incomplete CCTV evidence justify granting regular bail in a robbery case with prior antecedents.
judgment_reason: The court held that over two years of custody without trial progress, the lack of test identification parade, and incomplete CCTV panchanama justified bail under stringent conditions. The accused was ordered to stay outside Pune and report weekly to police.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Abhishek Sasane after 2 years in custody for robbery, citing procedural lapses and trial delay.

case_title: Harwinder Singh @ Bhinda vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Fourth regular bail application rejected due to involvement in multiple heinous crimes, including prior cases of robbery and arms offences, and possibility of influencing witnesses.
facts: Harwinder Singh @ Bhinda was accused in a violent incident involving snatching a Fortuner car at gunpoint, followed by a police chase and exchange of fire. During the encounter, some co-accused were injured and later died. The petitioner fled but was later apprehended with arms. He disclosed involvement in various robberies and violent crimes across Punjab, Haryana, and Rajasthan.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted after over 6 years of custody when the accused is involved in multiple serious criminal cases and the trial is ongoing at a slow pace.
judgment_reason: The court held that despite long custody, the gravity of offences and criminal antecedents of the petitioner made him unfit for bail. It also noted the real apprehension of witness tampering. However, it directed the trial court to expedite the proceedings.
summary: Punjab and Haryana High Court rejected Harwinder Singh’s fourth bail plea in a violent robbery case, citing grave allegations, past criminal record, and threat to fair trial.

case_title: Golu @ Goldi vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh
court: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench
judge: Justice Subodh Abhyankar, Justice Satyendra Kumar Singh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail denied as the applicant had a long criminal history and had previously misused bail by committing a bomb blast; forged documents were also submitted in an attempt to claim juvenile status.
facts: Golu @ Goldi filed for release claiming he was a juvenile at the time of the offence committed in 2006. He submitted baptism and school certificates to prove his age. However, the court noted that he had a history of 13 criminal cases and had previously misused bail by committing another offence involving a bomb blast. The submitted documents were suspected to be forged, and the father was even tried for this but acquitted for lack of proof.
legal_issues: Whether the accused was a juvenile at the time of the incident and thus eligible for release under the Juvenile Justice Act, despite his long criminal record and misuse of bail.
judgment_reason: The court found the claim of juvenility unconvincing due to forged documents, misuse of earlier bail, and criminal history. It dismissed the application as meritless.
summary: Madhya Pradesh High Court denied bail to Golu @ Goldi, rejecting his juvenility claim and noting past misuse of bail and a long criminal record.

case_title: Ishrail Ali vs The State Govt NCT Of Delhi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected; the court found sufficient material including CCTV footage, car identification, and partial recovery linking the accused to the robbery.
facts: The complainant alleged that while resting in his truck, four persons including one with a pistol (later found to be a toy) entered, beat his helper, and robbed ₹4 lakhs. CCTV showed the getaway vehicle used by the accused. The car owner confirmed that Ishrail Ali had taken the vehicle. ₹80,000 was recovered from the accused.
legal_issues: Whether the use of a toy pistol constitutes 'use of deadly weapon' under Section 397 IPC, and whether the accused’s identification via CCTV and recovery justifies denial of bail.
judgment_reason: The Court held that brandishing a toy pistol still invoked Section 397 IPC as it induced fear. The accused was directly linked through vehicle use, CCTV evidence, and recovery. Trial was yet to begin.
summary: Delhi High Court rejected regular bail to Ishrail Ali in a robbery case involving a toy pistol, relying on CCTV, witness statements, and partial recovery.
legal_principles_discussed: ["Use of toy pistol still constitutes 'use of weapon' under Section 397 IPC if it causes fear", 'Section 397 applies individually; joint liability requires separate consideration under Section 34 IPC']

case_title: Aekanbhai Rupabhai @ Rupsinghbhai vs State Of Gujarat
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted as the charge sheet was filed, recovery from the accused was minor, no criminal antecedents were found, and improper reliance was placed on statements of co-accused.
facts: Aekanbhai Rupabhai @ Rupsinghbhai was arrested in a case involving theft and robbery where ₹1.85 lakhs and ornaments were allegedly looted. Out of the alleged loot, only ₹6,200 was recovered from the accused. The Court noted that he had no prior criminal record and observed that statements of co-accused were improperly used to deny bail at the Sessions level.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted when the accused has no antecedents, minimal recovery was made, and the Sessions Court improperly relied on inadmissible statements.
judgment_reason: The Court held that the applicant should be granted regular bail due to absence of prior criminal history, minor recovery, and improper reliance on co-accused's statements. It relied on principles laid down in Sanjay Chandra v. CBI regarding grant of bail.
summary: Gujarat High Court granted regular bail to Aekanbhai Rupabhai @ Rupsinghbhai in a theft and robbery case, citing minimal recovery and no criminal antecedents.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Inadmissibility of co-accused statements without corroboration for denying bail', 'Bail may be granted where investigation is over, charge sheet filed, and accused has clean record', 'Sanjay Chandra v. CBI guidelines for bail consideration']

case_title: Shivam Singh vs State Of Chhattisgarh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Anticipatory bail granted as FIR initially excluded Section 395 IPC and noted robbery allegations were found false during inquiry; applicants had already been granted police bail before additional charges were added.
facts: The complainants alleged that on 2 May 2020, Shivam Singh and co-accused attacked them with weapons, looted a mobile phone and a gold chain, and assaulted them. The accused claimed the incident stemmed from a confrontation during threshing of wheat, where the complainants, allegedly intoxicated, attacked them. The initial inquiry by police found the robbery claim to be false, and bailable offences were first registered. Later, under pressure, Section 395 IPC and other names were added.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail should be granted when the original FIR findings ruled out robbery and police initially granted bail for bailable offences, later escalated under alleged pressure.
judgment_reason: The court noted that Section 395 IPC was added only after initial findings that the robbery claim was false. The mobile phone was found at the scene. The court concluded that anticipatory bail was justified in view of these facts.
summary: Chhattisgarh High Court granted anticipatory bail to Shivam Singh and others, citing the initial police finding that robbery allegations were false and later charges appeared influenced.

case_title: Jijo @Karumbuse vs State Of Kerala
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to applicants’ extensive criminal history and violation of prior bail conditions; involvement in gang-related violent crimes noted.
facts: On 18 October 2019, the applicants allegedly attacked the complainant with weapons and attempted to set him on fire using petrol and a matchstick, in an apparent gang-related assault due to prior enmity. They had been granted bail earlier but violated conditions and engaged in more criminal activity. The bail was subsequently cancelled. Although a settlement was claimed, their criminal background hindered fresh bail.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted to repeat offenders with serious criminal antecedents, despite claimed settlement with the complainant.
judgment_reason: The Court refused bail due to the applicants’ involvement in multiple past crimes (27 for one, 11 for the other), gang membership, and failure to comply with earlier bail conditions. It advised they may apply again after committal to Sessions Court.
summary: Kerala High Court denied bail to Jijo and co-accused citing their gang affiliations, prior criminal record, and violation of earlier bail terms.

case_title: Laxman Alias Lachuma S/O Venkataramana vs The State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted on grounds of parity with co-accused already released; prior criminal cases not considered sufficient to deny bail.
facts: On 29 August 2022, Laxman and others allegedly assembled with weapons near Devaragudda Road intending to commit robbery. Upon seeing patrolling police, the accused fled, and only two were caught on the spot. Items like iron rods, ropes, and knives were recovered from the vehicle. Laxman was arrested later in February 2024. He sought bail citing parity with co-accused already released.
legal_issues: Whether the applicant is entitled to bail on grounds of parity despite having multiple prior cases, when co-accused arrested on the spot have already been granted bail.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail noting that co-accused arrested on the spot had already been granted bail and held that the mere existence of prior cases is not enough to deny bail. The applicant had also undertaken to attend trial.
summary: Karnataka High Court granted bail to Laxman on grounds of parity with co-accused, despite prior criminal cases, in a robbery preparation case.

case_title: 395/120B/412 Of The Indian Penal Code vs In Re: Amarendra Kumar Singh @ Amar Singh
judge: Justice Prasenjit Biswas, Justice Joymalya Bagchi
accused_name: Amarendra Kumar Singh @ Amar Singh @ Pahalwan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after over two years in custody; court cited prolonged trial delay, absence at crime scene, and earlier liberty from Supreme Court to reapply for bail.
facts: Amarendra Kumar Singh was accused of conspiring and participating in a robbery at the office of a finance company. He was in custody for over two years and three months. His previous bail applications had been rejected by the High Court and Supreme Court, the latter granting liberty to reapply after six months. Only one witness had been examined during this time, and the trial was delayed due to co-accused being tried in another court.
legal_issues: Whether continued detention is justified when trial is delayed, co-accused are being tried separately, and the accused was not present at the crime scene.
judgment_reason: The court noted the prolonged detention, trial delay, and absence of the accused at the crime scene. It concluded that further detention was not warranted and granted bail subject to strict conditions to ensure presence and prevent tampering.
summary: Calcutta High Court granted regular bail to Amarendra Kumar Singh after over two years of custody in a robbery case, citing trial delays and his absence at the crime scene.

case_title: Arun Kumar vs State By Rajankunte Police
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as the petitioner was found to be a habitual offender involved in 11 serious criminal cases, including robbery, dacoity, murder, and kidnapping.
facts: On 13 June 2022, the complainant was lured to a toll booth by accused No.2. There, Arun Kumar and another co-accused abducted him, forced him to consume alcohol, assaulted him, and then demanded ransom from his mother for his release. Arun Kumar was arrested on 22 June 2022 and remained in custody.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to an accused in a kidnapping and robbery case who is a habitual offender with multiple serious prior cases.
judgment_reason: The Court rejected bail due to the accused’s history of involvement in 11 serious criminal offences and concluded that releasing him posed a risk of further similar crimes.
summary: Karnataka High Court denied bail to Arun Kumar in a kidnapping and robbery case, citing his status as a habitual offender and risk of future offences.

case_title: Mange Lal vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to applicant's habitual criminal conduct and recovery of incriminating items from co-accused traveling with him during a robbery raid.
facts: Mange Lal was arrested during a police raid on 30 September 2020, following a robbery complaint from the day before involving theft of gold and silver ornaments. He was caught along with two co-accused on a motorcycle. While no items were recovered directly from him, co-accused were found with weapons and stolen property. The prosecution claimed his habitual involvement in similar robbery cases.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused has a history of robbery-related offences and was apprehended with co-accused from whom incriminating items were recovered.
judgment_reason: The Court noted the accused’s prior involvement in multiple robbery incidents and recovery of stolen property from co-accused traveling with him. It rejected the claim of parity with other bail orders, emphasizing the accused's habitual criminal conduct.
summary: Allahabad High Court denied bail to Mange Lal citing his habitual criminal record and circumstantial evidence linking him to a recent robbery.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail is the rule and jail is the exception', 'Courts must consider criminal antecedents and recovery from co-accused', 'Ground of parity is a relevant but not decisive factor in bail consideration']

case_title: Danish Khan vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh
court: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Jabalpur Bench
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Seventh regular bail application granted due to prolonged custody since 2018 and pandemic conditions; earlier criminal cases resulted in acquittal.
facts: Danish Khan was arrested on 23 May 2018 for alleged robbery under Sections 392 and 397 IPC. Despite multiple prior criminal cases, he was acquitted in Sessions Trials Nos. 41/2018, 42/2018, and 43/2018. The bail plea cited prolonged incarceration and COVID-19-related delays in trial proceedings.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted considering long pre-trial custody, acquittal in related cases, and trial delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail noting the accused’s continued custody since 2018, acquittals in previous related trials, and pandemic-related delay in completion of trial. Bail was allowed with standard conditions.
summary: Madhya Pradesh High Court granted bail to Danish Khan after three years in custody, considering his acquittals and pandemic-related delays in trial.

case_title: Binod Sahni vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to multiple prior criminal antecedents involving theft and robbery; court advised renewal post charge framing.
facts: Binod Sahni was arrested after a country-made pistol, two live cartridges, and a stolen motorcycle were recovered from his possession. He had been in custody since August 6, 2017, and had multiple past criminal records related to theft and robbery.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to an accused with repeated criminal antecedents and recovery of illegal arms and stolen property.
judgment_reason: The court rejected the bail plea due to the petitioner’s history of theft and robbery and the nature of the current offence. However, it allowed the petitioner to renew his bail application after the framing of charges.
summary: Patna High Court denied bail to Binod Sahni citing his history of theft and robbery and recovery of illegal arms and a stolen motorcycle.

case_title: Waseem Alias Raj Alias Nepali vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after nearly 7 years of custody due to prolonged trial, lack of direct naming in FIR, and witness retraction.
facts: Waseem was accused of involvement in a 2018 home invasion and robbery in which Maya Devi was killed and her husband injured. Though not named in the FIR, a witness later claimed to have seen Waseem begging near the house a day prior. The defense argued the recovery was not independently corroborated, and that the key witness later retracted. Waseem had no criminal history prior to this case.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged custody without trial progress and absence of direct evidence justify bail in a dacoity-cum-murder case under Sections 396 and 412 IPC.
judgment_reason: The court noted the accused had been in custody since June 2018, the key witness had retracted in court, no independent recovery was made, and the trial had stagnated despite earlier directives to expedite. It allowed bail on strict conditions.
summary: Allahabad High Court granted bail to Waseem after nearly 7 years in custody in a dacoity-cum-murder case, citing stalled trial and witness retraction.

case_title: Vishal Kumar Saw vs The State Of Jharkhand
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 9 months in custody; co-accused was already granted bail and charge had been framed.
facts: Vishal Kumar Saw was accused in a road robbery case registered under Chaibasa Muffasil P.S. Case No.177 of 2022. He had been in custody since November 2022. The charge was framed on 2 May 2023, and a co-accused was granted bail earlier. The petitioner renewed his bail plea, affirming there was no suppression and offering full cooperation with trial proceedings.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted after framing of charge and when a co-accused has already been granted bail in a road robbery case.
judgment_reason: The court considered the duration of custody, completion of charge framing, and parity with co-accused already granted bail. Bail was allowed with standard conditions.
summary: Jharkhand High Court granted bail to Vishal Kumar Saw in a road robbery case, citing prolonged custody and bail granted to co-accused.

case_title: Ratan Lal Tanti vs The State Of Jharkhand
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after over a year in custody; victim had been examined and failed to identify the accused.
facts: Ratan Lal Tanti was accused in a robbery case registered under Tonto P.S. Case No.27 of 2022. He had been in custody since 31 August 2022. His earlier bail plea had been rejected, but he renewed the application citing that the victim had already been examined and had not identified him during testimony.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the victim fails to identify the accused during trial testimony after prolonged pre-trial detention.
judgment_reason: The court considered the victim’s testimony where he failed to identify the applicant as a perpetrator and granted bail subject to conditions, including providing Aadhaar and mobile contact details.
summary: Jharkhand High Court granted bail to Ratan Lal Tanti in a robbery case, noting that the victim failed to identify him during trial and he had been in custody for over a year.

case_title: Gaurav vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh
court: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Gwalior Bench
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Second bail application allowed after charge-sheet filing; bail granted with conditions including deposit to Legal Aid Services and compliance with COVID-19 protocols.
facts: The applicant Gaurav was arrested on 04 July 2021 for alleged involvement in a robbery case under Section 394 IPC. His name was not mentioned in the FIR. The charge-sheet had been filed and trial was expected to take time. The applicant agreed to conditions including a monetary deposit to Legal Aid Services.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted when the FIR does not name the accused, the charge-sheet is filed, and the trial is likely to be delayed.
judgment_reason: The Court granted bail citing the filing of the charge-sheet, the absence of the applicant’s name in the FIR, and anticipated trial delay. Conditions were imposed to ensure cooperation and compliance.
summary: Madhya Pradesh High Court granted regular bail to Gaurav in a robbery case after charge-sheet filing and noting he was not named in the FIR.

case_title: Pappu Kumar @ Pappu Rai vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to recovery of loaded pistol and live cartridges from possession, and petitioner’s criminal antecedents including dacoity and robbery.
facts: Pappu Kumar @ Pappu Rai was arrested on 08 November 2017 following a police raid based on secret information about an assembly of criminals. From his possession, a loaded country-made pistol and three live cartridges were recovered. He had three prior criminal cases involving dacoity and robbery.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to an accused caught with illegal arms during a criminal assembly with past convictions for similar serious offences.
judgment_reason: The Court declined bail due to the seriousness of the offence, direct recovery of weapons, and the accused’s criminal antecedents. However, it directed the trial court to expedite proceedings.
summary: Patna High Court denied bail to Pappu Kumar @ Pappu Rai, citing weapon recovery and his history of dacoity and robbery; trial court directed to expedite case.

case_title: Achi vs The Station House Officer
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted taking into account custody duration, charge-sheet filing, and conditions imposed for release.
facts: The accused, Achi, allegedly attempted to rob a bracelet from a child at Comtrust Hospital in Kozhikode. She was apprehended by hospital staff on suspicion and identified by the defacto complainant. She was in custody, and the charge-sheet was already filed by the time of this bail application.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted under Section 439 CrPC after the charge-sheet has been filed and considering judicial custody already undergone.
judgment_reason: The court considered the nature of the offence, the time spent in judicial custody, and the fact that charges were already filed. Bail was granted subject to conditions including local sureties and restrictions on influencing witnesses.
summary: Kerala High Court granted regular bail to Achi in an attempted robbery case, citing time in custody and charge-sheet filing.

case_title: Sanjeet Kumar vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to recovery of loaded country-made pistol and prior criminal record including two robbery cases.
facts: Sanjeet Kumar was apprehended by police while riding a motorcycle, and a country-made loaded pistol with two live cartridges was found in his possession. He had been in custody since June 14, 2017. Although a co-accused was granted bail, Sanjeet's prior criminal history involving two robbery cases led to the rejection of his bail plea.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted in an arms possession case when the accused has prior robbery-related criminal antecedents.
judgment_reason: The Court denied bail due to the serious nature of the offence under the Arms Act and the petitioner's prior involvement in robbery cases, though it allowed for a future bail application post charge-framing.
summary: Patna High Court rejected bail to Sanjeet Kumar in an arms case due to his criminal antecedents involving robbery and the recovery of a loaded weapon.

case_title: Somar Yadav vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to the accused's involvement in 12 prior criminal cases and being apprehended while fleeing from the robbery scene.
facts: Somar Yadav was arrested along with co-accused Birendra Yadav while fleeing from the scene after allegedly committing robbery in a shop. Although the co-accused had been granted bail, Somar Yadav was found to have 12 prior criminal cases against him. His earlier bail request was rejected in March 2015, and this was a renewed application.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused was caught at the scene and has multiple past criminal cases despite co-accused getting bail.
judgment_reason: The court rejected the bail application citing the accused’s extensive criminal record and direct apprehension during the crime. The court also directed the trial court to conclude proceedings within six months, after which the petitioner could reapply.
summary: Patna High Court denied bail to Somar Yadav in a robbery case, noting his prior criminal history and arrest while fleeing the crime scene.

case_title: Subhash Choudhary Alias Subhash vs The State Of Jharkhand
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after co-accused received bail in similar circumstances; petitioner had been earlier denied bail due to recovery but was later considered on parity.
facts: Subhash Choudhary was accused in a robbery case registered as Kotwali P.S. Case No. 779 of 2014. Initially charged under Section 392 IPC, the charge-sheet was later submitted under Section 395 IPC. Earlier bail was denied due to recovery from the petitioner. However, a co-accused was granted bail on 16 July 2015, and the petitioner reapplied citing parity.
legal_issues: Whether the petitioner should be granted bail on the ground of parity after earlier denial due to recovery from his possession.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail considering that a co-accused in similar circumstances had already been granted bail, and thus parity applied.
summary: Jharkhand High Court granted regular bail to Subhash Choudhary in a robbery case, noting similar bail granted to a co-accused earlier.

case_title: Ranjit Kumar @ Ranjit Chaudhari vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after nearly two years in custody with no charge framing; bail given with strict conditions including verified address and mandatory court appearances.
facts: Ranjit Kumar was accused in a highway robbery case (Bihta P.S. Case No.445 of 2017) and was named in witness statements. His earlier bail application was rejected in 2018, with the trial court instructed to expedite the trial. By 2019, he had been in custody for about two years without charge being framed, which formed the basis for his renewed bail plea.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged custody without charge framing justifies grant of bail in a highway robbery case.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail due to prolonged pre-charge custody and directed that bailors be local, address verification be conducted, and the petitioner comply with all future court dates.
summary: Patna High Court granted bail to Ranjit Kumar in a highway robbery case due to nearly two years of custody without charge framing.

case_title: Rabish @ Shahzada Khan vs State Of Jharkhand
judge: Justice H. C. Mishra, Justice Dr. S.N. Pathak
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as bloodstained knife and looted items were recovered based on the appellant’s confessional statement in a robbery and murder case.
facts: The case involves the robbery and murder of a woman. Rabish @ Shahzada Khan was accused based on his confessional statement which led to the recovery of looted articles and a bloodstained knife. He had been in custody for approximately nine years at the time of the bail application.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted during the pendency of appeal when incriminating items were recovered on the basis of the appellant’s confession.
judgment_reason: The court rejected the bail application due to the recovery of a bloodstained knife and stolen property based on the appellant's confessional statement, suggesting strong prima facie involvement.
summary: Jharkhand High Court rejected bail for Rabish @ Shahzada Khan in a robbery and murder case, citing recovery of a bloodstained knife and looted goods based on his confession.

case_title: Hasmukh D. Prajapati vs State Of Gujarat
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail and multiple parole applications rejected due to misuse of process and misleading the court and authorities using false medical grounds; parole granted by Minister was later suspended by the High Court as illegal.
facts: Hasmukh D. Prajapati was convicted along with others for a pre-planned bank robbery of ₹12 lakhs involving armed assault, vehicle tampering, and firing to create terror. After conviction, he repeatedly sought temporary bail citing his son’s illness. Despite bail rejections, he secured parole through political influence and misrepresentation. The High Court later suspended the parole, declaring it unlawful.
legal_issues: Whether parole can be granted by a State Minister bypassing statutory authorities, and whether repeated medical grounds after prior rejections can justify release.
judgment_reason: The court held that parole must be granted strictly as per statutory rules by designated jail authorities and not by ministers acting arbitrarily. The applicant misused the legal process, and medical grounds were found to be exaggerated or unverified. His parole was suspended, and he was ordered to surrender.
summary: Gujarat High Court rejected parole to Hasmukh D. Prajapati in a bank robbery case, criticizing misuse of political influence and illegal parole grant by a State Minister.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Parole can only be granted by designated jail authorities as per Rule 18 of the Prisons (Bombay Furlough and Parole) Rules, 1959', 'Political recommendation cannot override statutory requirements in criminal justice', 'Repeated applications on the same ground already rejected cannot justify relief']

case_title: Mohammed Ashik vs The State
accused_name: Mohammed Ashik and Isaak @ Icchu Jaffar Sadik
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to multiple criminal antecedents across Karnataka, use of stolen vehicle in crime, and risk of absconding or repeating similar offences.
facts: On 5 March 2022, complainant Mustaf was intercepted by two armed men in a red car and robbed of ₹2,15,000. He was later hospitalized and filed a police complaint. Investigation linked Mohammed Ashik and Isaak, already in custody for another case, to the robbery. Though money was not recovered, their involvement was supported by car seizure and confessional statements. Both had prior criminal cases involving dacoity and robbery across Karnataka.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted to accused with multiple prior offences and no recovery of stolen cash in a violent robbery case.
judgment_reason: The Court held that despite absence of monetary recovery, the accused's involvement in numerous cases, use of a stolen vehicle with fake registration, and risk of fleeing warranted bail denial. Their past conduct indicated potential threat to public safety.
summary: Karnataka High Court denied bail to Mohammed Ashik and Isaak citing their criminal history, use of stolen car, and likelihood of repeating offences.

case_title: Shivgopal @ Raja vs State Of U.P. And 3 Others
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to gravity of offences, including gang rape and robbery, and identification of the applicant as principal offender.
facts: Shivgopal @ Raja was arrested in connection with Case Crime No. 557 of 2022 involving gang rape and robbery. He was identified as the principal offender and had been in custody since 15.09.2022. The offences included serious charges under IPC and POCSO Act. The trial is ongoing.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to an accused identified as the principal offender in a gang rape and robbery case involving multiple serious charges under IPC and POCSO Act.
judgment_reason: The Court declined bail citing the gravity of offences and identification of the applicant as principal offender. It directed the trial court to expedite the proceedings within a year and ensure strict compliance with witness attendance and procedural timelines.
summary: Allahabad High Court rejected bail to Shivgopal @ Raja in a gang rape and robbery case, emphasizing the serious nature of the charges and ordering expedited trial.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Expeditious trial mandated under Section 309 Cr.P.C.', 'Trial courts must actively ensure attendance of witnesses and avoid delays', 'Strict scrutiny applies in cases involving POCSO and gang rape charges']

case_title: Kailash Babu vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to prima facie involvement in brutal murder and robbery; recovery of bloodstained weapon and stolen money supported prosecution’s case.
facts: The applicant, Kailash Babu, was accused of murdering a woman with multiple stab wounds and committing robbery at her residence. The FIR initially registered under Section 307 IPC was later updated to include Sections 302, 394, and 411 IPC after the victim succumbed to her injuries and missing items were reported. A bloodstained weapon was recovered from his possession, and co-accused had named him in a confessional statement.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when recovery of murder weapon and stolen property links the accused to a brutal murder and robbery, despite reliance on co-accused’s confessional statement.
judgment_reason: The court noted the nature of the crime, the recovery of incriminating material from the accused, and the brutal manner of the killing. It found sufficient prima facie evidence to deny bail and directed that trial issues be addressed in due course.
summary: Allahabad High Court rejected regular bail to Kailash Babu in a brutal murder and robbery case, citing recovery of weapon and stolen money as prima facie evidence.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Confessional statements of co-accused are weak evidence but recovery may independently implicate an accused', 'Bail may be denied if prima facie case is supported by material evidence such as recovery', 'Seriousness of offence and brutality involved are key considerations in bail decisions']

case_title: Javid Ahmad Shah vs Union Territory Of J&K Through SHO P/S Pulwama
court: Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh High Court, Srinagar Bench
judge: Justice Ali Mohammad Magrey, Justice Md. Akram Chowdhary
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail pending appeal was rejected as the trial court's conviction was based on strong circumstantial, oral, medical, and forensic evidence in a murder and robbery case.
facts: Javid Ahmad Shah was convicted for murder and robbery in a case involving the killing of a student named Khursheed Ahmad Wani. The body was found under cow dung at Muran Pulwama. Witnesses, including an approver, stated that Javid and co-accused beat the victim to death in a tin shed. Javid was sentenced to life imprisonment under Section 302 and one year under Section 392. He applied for bail pending appeal after over 10 years in custody.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted pending appeal when the conviction is based on robust evidence and the appeal has not been pending for more than 5–6 years.
judgment_reason: The Court held that in serious offences like murder, bail pending appeal may only be granted after the appeal remains undecided for 5–6 years. Since Javid’s appeal was filed recently and the conviction was based on strong evidence, bail was denied.
summary: J&K High Court rejected bail pending appeal for Javid Ahmad Shah, convicted of murder and robbery, citing strong evidence and recent filing of appeal.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Suspension of sentence in serious offences like murder requires exceptional circumstances', 'No presumption of innocence after conviction by trial court', 'Delay in disposal of appeal may justify bail only after 5–6 years']

case_title: Babu S/O Chandrappa vs The State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as accused were caught red-handed attempting to commit robbery by impersonating police and using a knife; not found similarly placed to co-accused who was granted bail.
facts: On the night of 31 October 2022, Babu and a co-accused impersonated police officers and stopped a vehicle at O.P. Circle, Ballari. They demanded documents and ₹20,000 from the complainant and his friends. When the complainant refused, the accused threatened them with a knife. The real police arrived, and Babu and his accomplice were apprehended while a third accomplice escaped. A knife was seized from the accused.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted to accused caught in the act of attempted robbery by impersonating police and using a knife, especially when another co-accused was granted bail under different circumstances.
judgment_reason: The Court held that Babu and the co-accused were not similarly placed to the third accused who had been granted bail, as they were caught red-handed with a weapon. Ongoing investigation and risk of interference with evidence also justified bail denial.
summary: Karnataka High Court denied bail to Babu in an impersonation and attempted robbery case, finding he was caught red-handed with a weapon and not similarly placed to a co-accused who was granted bail.

case_title: Altaf S/O Kutabuddin Ainapur vs The State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted despite two pending cases of minor nature, as co-accused had already been granted bail and no vehicle was proven to have been stopped during the alleged attempted robbery.
facts: On 1 August 2022 at around 2:00 a.m., Altaf and others were found near Nayara Petrol Bunk with rods, ropes, a knife, and chilli powder, allegedly intending to commit robbery. Police apprehended five accused while others fled. No actual robbery occurred and no vehicle was proven to have been stopped. Altaf was denied bail by the Sessions Court but re-applied as other co-accused were granted bail and his prior cases were minor.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused was found with potential weapons but no overt act of robbery occurred and co-accused were already released.
judgment_reason: The Court noted that no robbery was actually committed, prior cases against the petitioner were minor (Sections 323, 504, 506 IPC), and co-accused had already received bail. It granted bail subject to stringent conditions.
summary: Karnataka High Court granted bail to Altaf Ainapur in an attempted robbery case, noting no overt act was committed and co-accused had been granted bail.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail is the rule and rejection is an exception', 'Minor pending cases do not make one a habitual offender', 'Parity with co-accused is a relevant consideration in bail applications']

case_title: Jacob Imanual Shivapur vs The State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted as the accused was caught preparing for dacoity, but had no prior criminal record and was similarly placed to co-accused already granted bail.
facts: On 15 November 2021, police received information about five suspicious persons at Mahadwar Road, Belagavi. They were apprehended with weapons including a knife, jambe, chilli powder, and monkey caps. The accused, including Jacob Imanual Shivapur, admitted they were preparing to commit robbery or dacoity. Jacob was arrested and remained in custody, with no prior criminal antecedents.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused is caught during preparation to commit dacoity but has no criminal record and is similarly placed to co-accused already granted bail.
judgment_reason: The court noted that the accused was in custody since 15.11.2021, had no criminal antecedents, and was similarly placed to co-accused already granted bail. Bail was granted with conditions to prevent interference with the investigation.
summary: Karnataka High Court granted bail to Jacob Imanual Shivapur in a dacoity preparation case, noting absence of prior criminal record and parity with co-accused.

case_title: Dhavalsinh Balubha Sodha vs State Of Gujarat
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted due to amicable settlement between parties, absence of criminal antecedents, and no risk of absconding or evidence tampering.
facts: Dhavalsinh Balubha Sodha was arrested in connection with FIR I-C.R.No.29 of 2019 for offences of kidnapping and robbery under IPC and Gujarat Police Act, along with Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act provisions. The complainant later filed an affidavit indicating an amicable resolution, and raised no objection to bail.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted in serious IPC and Atrocities Act offences when the parties have resolved the dispute amicably and the accused has no criminal history.
judgment_reason: The Court noted the mutual resolution of the dispute, lack of criminal antecedents, and no apprehension of the accused absconding or influencing witnesses. Based on these factors, regular bail was granted.
summary: Gujarat High Court granted bail to Dhavalsinh Balubha Sodha in a kidnapping and robbery case, citing amicable resolution and no prior criminal history.

case_title: Padeep vs The State Of M.P.
court: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Gwalior Bench
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted in view of Supreme Court guidelines on decongesting prisons during COVID-19 and considering the accused's continued custody since April 2020.
facts: Pradeep was arrested on 19 April 2020 in connection with a robbery involving ₹3,000. He was booked under Section 392 IPC and MPDVPK Act. The defense argued false implication and delay in trial due to the pandemic. The court took note of Supreme Court directions for prisoner release amid COVID-19.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted during the COVID-19 pandemic for an accused in custody for a non-heinous offence with low recovery amount.
judgment_reason: Bail was granted considering prolonged custody during COVID-19, low amount involved in the offence, and the need to decongest prisons as per Supreme Court guidelines.
summary: Madhya Pradesh High Court granted regular bail to Pradeep in a ₹3,000 robbery case, considering COVID-19 conditions and Supreme Court directions.
legal_principles_discussed: ['SC guidelines on decongesting prisons during COVID-19', 'Bail permissible for offences with punishment up to 7 years']

case_title: Azad vs State
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected in a bank robbery case due to similarity with co-accused whose bail had been denied; no recovery of arms or money from petitioner, but court found collective liability.
facts: Azad was arrested in connection with a bank robbery case registered under FIR No. 231/2019 at Police Station Sidhmukh, Churu. While no weapons or stolen money were recovered from him, eleven mobile phones were seized. He had been in judicial custody at the time of the bail application. Co-accused had already been denied bail.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when there is no direct recovery from the accused, but his case is similar to co-accused already denied bail in a collective offence.
judgment_reason: The Court denied bail citing the collective nature of the bank robbery, similarity with co-accused whose bail was rejected, and seriousness of the charges. It directed the trial court to expedite proceedings.
summary: Rajasthan High Court denied bail to Azad in a bank robbery case, finding his case similar to co-accused and emphasizing collective criminal involvement.

case_title: Sunil vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted on second application due to prolonged detention and trial delay
facts: The accused, Sunil, was alleged to have committed robbery of a tempo and had been in jail since 31.10.2020. His first bail application was rejected, and this was his second application citing long detention and trial delay with no charges framed yet.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged detention without framing of charges justifies bail under Article 21 of the Constitution.
judgment_reason: The court considered prolonged detention, absence of criminal history, and delay in trial while referencing Article 21 and Supreme Court precedents to grant bail.
summary: Bail granted to Sunil due to extended pre-trial detention and delay in framing charges. No prior criminal history noted.

case_title: Jitendra Jaiswal vs State Of Chhattisgarh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted on account of prolonged detention and pending trial despite serious allegations
facts: Jitendra Jaiswal and co-accused allegedly robbed Rs. 52,000 and a mobile phone from a complainant's shop and threatened further extortion. The FIR was delayed, and the applicant has been in jail since 08/04/2022. He claims false implication due to his work as a journalist.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged detention and pending trial justify bail despite allegations of robbery and criminal antecedents.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail considering the nature of the offense, delay in trial, and prolonged detention, while noting that the applicant has been in custody for nearly ten months.
summary: Bail granted to journalist accused of robbery after ten months in custody due to trial delay. Court noted seriousness but prioritized right to liberty.

case_title: Sri. Santosh S/O. Nandu Bosle vs State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to identification by complainant, habitual offender record, and involvement in dacoity and murder cases
facts: The accused, along with co-accused, allegedly broke into a home at night, assaulted the residents, and stole gold ornaments and cash. The complainant identified the petitioner. The petitioner was implicated based on a co-accused’s statement and is alleged to be a habitual offender involved in multiple robbery and murder cases across states.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused is a habitual offender identified by the complainant and involved in serious offenses like dacoity and murder.
judgment_reason: Court denied bail due to seriousness of the crime, complainant's identification, petitioner’s criminal history, and high flight risk.
summary: Bail denied to accused Santosh due to identification by victim, habitual offender record, and serious charges including dacoity and murder.

case_title: Chandan @ Chandu Majhi vs Unknown
judge: Justice Harish Tandon, Justice Bibek Chaudhuri
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as petitioner was identified in Test Identification Parade and money was recovered based on his statement
facts: The case involves a bank robbery where Chandan @ Chandu Majhi was apprehended. Unlike a co-accused who was granted bail, Chandan was identified in a Test Identification Parade and cash was recovered on his statement.
legal_issues: Whether the identification of the accused and recovery of cash justify continued detention despite co-accused being granted bail.
judgment_reason: Court found no change in circumstances since earlier bail rejection; identification and recovery justified continued detention.
summary: Bail rejected for Chandan Majhi due to Test ID and recovery of cash linking him to a bank robbery. Co-accused had been granted bail under different facts.

case_title: Shakeer Khan vs State Of Chhattisgarh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected considering seriousness of attempted dacoity in a bank and co-accused’s bail rejection
facts: Shakeer Khan was arrested for allegedly attempting to commit dacoity in Vijaya Bank, Rajnandgaon along with other co-accused. He has been in jail since 23.12.2015. The charge sheet has been filed.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a serious offense involving attempted bank dacoity when co-accused have also been denied bail.
judgment_reason: Court denied bail due to gravity of the offense, the coordinated nature of the bank dacoity attempt, and rejection of bail for co-accused.
summary: Bail rejected for Shakeer Khan in bank dacoity attempt case due to gravity of charges and earlier co-accused bail rejection.

case_title: Syed Sadiq vs State By The Psi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after chargesheet filed and recovery made; no criminal antecedents found
facts: Syed Sadiq and co-accused allegedly robbed a vehicle carrying 40 quintals of areca nut and Rs. 1,75,000 in cash after intercepting it with deadly weapons. The incident occurred on 02.11.2022 and the FIR was registered the next day. The accused were later identified and the robbed goods recovered based on voluntary statements.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when identification and recovery are completed and the accused have no prior criminal record.
judgment_reason: Bail was granted due to absence of prior criminal history, recovery of goods, filing of chargesheet, and identification already completed.
summary: Syed Sadiq granted bail in areca nut robbery case as investigation was complete, recovery made, and no prior record found.

case_title: Maragubhusain And Ors vs The State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite concerns over absconding risk; court found the offense not punishable with death or life imprisonment
facts: The complainant withdrew Rs. 1,01,500 from a bank and while walking with his mother, a person on a bicycle collided with him causing him to fall, after which another person stole Rs. 1,00,000 from his pocket. The accused were arrested based on a co-accused’s voluntary statement.
legal_issues: Whether accused from another state can be granted bail when the offense alleged does not involve violence or severe punishment.
judgment_reason: Court noted that the facts may not constitute robbery, the accused offered sureties, and mere residence in another state is insufficient ground to deny bail.
summary: Bail granted to four Uttar Pradesh-based accused in theft case as ingredients of robbery not established and they offered sureties.

case_title: Kantilal vs State Of Rajasthan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted considering simple injuries, no overt act, and absence of criminal antecedents
facts: Kantilal was arrested in connection with an alleged attempted robbery at a school in Bhilwara, Rajasthan. The prosecution claimed he and others planned the act and assaulted police during intervention. The defense argued he had no role in causing injuries and no criminal record. Injuries to victims were minor and caused by blunt weapons.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a planned robbery attempt case when the accused has no prior record and caused no direct harm.
judgment_reason: Court considered the minor nature of injuries, lack of recovery from the accused, absence of criminal history, and filed chargesheet to grant bail.
summary: Kantilal granted bail in school robbery attempt case due to simple injuries, no prior record, and completed investigation.

case_title: Amit Kumar Vishwakarma vs The State Of Jharkhand
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after prolonged custody and lack of recovery or TIP linking accused directly
facts: Amit Kumar Vishwakarma was arrested in connection with a bank robbery case. He had been in custody since 22.02.2023. His involvement was alleged based on co-accused statements, with no recovery or test identification parade conducted.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted in absence of direct recovery, TIP, and after prolonged custody.
judgment_reason: Court considered the period of custody and lack of direct evidence such as recovery or identification to grant bail.
summary: Amit Kumar Vishwakarma granted bail in bank robbery case due to long custody and lack of recovery or identification linking him.

case_title: Ajoy Singh Alias Ajay Singh vs Unknown
judge: Justice Arijit Banerjee, Justice Apurba Sinha Ray
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to seriousness of robbery involving stupefying substance despite prolonged custody and delay in trial
facts: Ajoy Singh alias Ajay Singh is accused in a robbery case where the victim was allegedly drugged using a stupefying substance. He has been in custody for over 393 days, with no criminal antecedents, and charges have not yet been framed due to procedural delays.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged custody without charge framing and absence of criminal history justify bail in a serious robbery case involving drugs.
judgment_reason: Court rejected bail considering the gravity of the offence and material in the case diary, despite expressing concern over trial delay.
summary: Bail denied to Ajoy Singh in robbery-by-drugging case; court emphasized offence seriousness while urging speedy trial.

case_title: Kailash Babu vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted after co-accused received bail; initial bail had been rejected
facts: The applicant, Kailash Babu, was accused in a case involving the brutal murder of a woman with multiple stab wounds and related robbery. Evidence included the recovery of a scissor allegedly used in the crime and stolen money from his bag. He had previously been denied bail. Bail was later granted after co-accused Manoj Kumar, who allegedly played a more direct role, was granted bail.
legal_issues: Whether parity with co-accused granted bail and slow pace of trial warrant bail to applicant despite prior rejection.
judgment_reason: The court considered the subsequent bail granted to co-accused Manoj Kumar, the slow pace of the trial, and found these sufficient grounds to allow bail to the applicant with strict conditions.
summary: Court granted regular bail to accused Kailash Babu due to parity with co-accused and slow trial progress. Bail was previously denied based on seriousness of offense.

case_title: Sunil Muduli vs State Of Odisha
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected during appeal due to criminal antecedents and severity of offense
facts: The petitioner, Sunil Muduli, was convicted of attempting to murder a woman by shooting her during an armed robbery. He was sentenced under IPC Sections 398, 307 with Section 34, and Sections 25 and 27 of the Arms Act. He is in custody since October 2021 and has 15 prior criminal cases. His bail plea during appeal was rejected by the trial court and again by the High Court.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted during appeal despite conviction for serious offenses and multiple criminal antecedents.
judgment_reason: Due to the serious nature of the offense, criminal antecedents involving 15 other cases, and conviction for armed robbery and attempted murder, the court denied bail during appeal.
summary: Bail during appeal was denied to Sunil Muduli due to the serious nature of the crime and extensive criminal record. The court found no merit in granting bail at this stage.

case_title: Naseer @ Guddu @ Pan vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Second bail application rejected; court held that co-accused bail cannot be used for parity due to higher recovery from applicant
facts: The applicant, Naseer @ Guddu @ Pan, was accused of committing a robbery of Rs. 9.5 lakhs along with co-accused Saleem and Nadeem @ Deepak. Rs. 1.28 lakhs were recovered from the applicant. His first bail application was rejected, and the second one was based on co-accused Nadeem getting bail. However, Nadeem had only Rs. 9300 recovered from him.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted on parity grounds when recovery amount significantly differs between co-accused.
judgment_reason: The court held that since a higher amount of stolen money was recovered from the applicant compared to the co-accused, whose bail was granted, the cases were not on parity and bail could not be granted.
summary: Second bail plea was rejected for Naseer @ Guddu @ Pan as he failed to establish parity with co-accused due to greater recovery from him. Court found no new ground for bail.

case_title: Syed Mansoor Ali Khan vs State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 9 months in custody with recovery of minor amount and simple injury to victim
facts: The petitioner was accused of robbing Rs. 9,500 and a mobile phone from a food vendor along with a co-accused. While co-accused was caught at the scene, the petitioner fled with the cash. He was arrested two days later and a portion of the stolen cash and the phone were recovered. He had been in custody for 9 months before being granted bail.
legal_issues: Whether continued custody was justified despite minor recovery and simple injury when trial was already committed to Sessions Court.
judgment_reason: The court noted the petitioner had already spent 9 months in custody, the injury caused was simple, investigation was complete, and the petitioner had only one previous case which ended in acquittal. Bail was granted with conditions.
summary: The High Court granted regular bail to Syed Mansoor Ali Khan considering prolonged custody, minor recovery, and completed investigation. Conditions were imposed to prevent tampering or repeat offense.

case_title: Umesh Paswan vs The State Of Bihar
judge: Justice Ashwani Kumar Singh, Justice Rajeev Ranjan Prasad
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail during appeal rejected; court cited gravity of murder committed during robbery and prior rejections
facts: The appellant, Umesh Paswan, was convicted under IPC Sections 302, 394, and 120B for participating in a murder committed during a robbery. He had already served over four years in custody and sought bail during the pendency of his appeal. His earlier bail pleas were rejected twice.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted during appeal despite serious conviction and previous rejections.
judgment_reason: Given the nature of the crime — murder during robbery — and supporting evidence of his involvement, the court found no justification to grant bail at this stage despite prolonged custody.
summary: Bail was denied to Umesh Paswan during appeal due to the gravity of the offense and prior rejections. He was convicted of murder during a robbery.

case_title: Badshah @ Riyaz Ahmad vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Third bail application granted due to prolonged custody and delay in trial during COVID-19; co-accused already granted bail
facts: The applicant was arrested in a robbery case involving Rs. 4,000, clothes, a mobile phone, and an ATM card. He was not named in the FIR, but Rs. 3,000 and a phone were later recovered from him. The recovered phone was not identified by the informant. He had been in jail since March 2016 and no progress had been made in trial proceedings due to COVID-19. Co-accused had already received bail.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration without trial and parity with co-accused warranted bail despite previous rejections.
judgment_reason: Considering the extended pre-trial detention, lack of trial progress, co-accused already being granted bail, and COVID-19 disruption, the court granted bail to uphold Article 21 rights.
summary: The court granted bail to the applicant after over four years in jail due to trial delays and parity with co-accused. Recovery evidence was weak and COVID-19 impacted court functioning.

case_title: Pramod vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Second bail application rejected; court found no new grounds post earlier rejection on merits
facts: The applicant, Pramod, was arrested in a murder and robbery case and has been in custody since January 2016. He was allegedly apprehended at the scene with a weapon. While co-accused were granted bail, his previous bail application was rejected in 2019. The trial has not progressed significantly due to COVID-19.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged custody without progress in trial and co-accused bail warrants fresh bail consideration.
judgment_reason: The court noted that the first bail was rejected on merits, and no new grounds were raised in the second application. Delay due to COVID-19 did not suffice for reconsideration.
summary: Second bail application of accused Pramod was denied, with court finding no fresh grounds beyond previous rejection. Trial delay due to pandemic was noted but not deemed sufficient.

case_title: Anil Kumar Mehta vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to petitioner’s involvement in three serious criminal cases including robbery and murder, and risk of associating with criminals or facing physical danger if released.
facts: Anil Kumar Mehta, a juvenile, was denied bail by both the Juvenile Justice Board and Sessions Judge. He had been in custody for over a year and was accused in Amba P.S. Case No. 38 of 2016 under the Arms Act. He also had three other pending cases involving robbery and murder under IPC Sections 393, 394, 302, and Arms Act Section 27.
legal_issues: Whether a juvenile with multiple serious criminal antecedents should be granted bail under Section 12 of the Juvenile Justice Act when release may pose physical or moral danger.
judgment_reason: The Court upheld bail denial due to risks under Section 12 of the Juvenile Justice Act, 2015, noting the juvenile’s criminal antecedents, potential association with known criminals, and threat to his own safety.
summary: Patna High Court denied bail to juvenile Anil Kumar Mehta citing multiple serious criminal cases and risk of harm or criminal association upon release.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail under Section 12 of the Juvenile Justice Act is the rule and denial is the exception', 'Denial justified if release exposes juvenile to danger or criminal association']

case_title: Ranjeet Kumar Sah @ Ranjit Kumar vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to recovery of arms and ammunition from the petitioner and his criminal antecedents involving four prior cases including Arms Act and robbery offences.
facts: The petitioner was apprehended by police while his associate allegedly fired upon the officers and escaped. Upon arrest, one country-made pistol, four live cartridges, and a magazine were recovered from the petitioner. He had been in custody for eight months at the time of the bail application and had four prior criminal cases.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted in a case involving recovery of illegal arms and prior criminal record of the accused under Section 307 IPC and Arms Act.
judgment_reason: The Court denied bail considering the nature of the offence, recovery of weapons, and the petitioner’s prior criminal record. However, it allowed the petitioner to renew his bail application if the trial was not concluded within six months.
summary: Patna High Court denied bail to Ranjeet Kumar Sah due to arms recovery and prior criminal record, but permitted reapplication after six months if the trial was delayed.

case_title: Dinesh Kumar @ Dinesh Yadav vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Anticipatory bail rejected as petitioner was named by a co-accused from whom arms were recovered during a police raid aimed at preventing robbery.
facts: Dinesh Kumar @ Dinesh Yadav was implicated in Fatuha P.S. Case No.550 of 2017 under Sections 399 and 402 IPC and Arms Act provisions. Police, acting on secret information, raided a location where a group was allegedly planning a robbery. One Ramanand Yadav was caught with arms; he named Dinesh as a co-conspirator. Dinesh claimed false implication and said he worked as a canteen boy.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail should be granted when the accused is named by a co-accused in a planned robbery case involving arms recovery.
judgment_reason: The Court found sufficient grounds in the statement of the apprehended co-accused and nature of the offence to reject anticipatory bail.
summary: Patna High Court rejected anticipatory bail to Dinesh Kumar Yadav, who was named by a co-accused caught with arms in a planned robbery case.

case_title: Sonu Kumar vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as this was the fourth attempt despite prior rejections; the petitioner had multiple past cases, mostly involving robbery.
facts: Sonu Kumar was in custody since 08 April 2016 in connection with Agamkuan P.S. Case No. 118 of 2016 under IPC Sections 399, 402 and Arms Act Sections 25(1-b)A, 26, and 35. He had five prior cases, mostly for robbery. This was his fourth bail application.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be reconsidered for an accused with multiple past robbery-related cases who has already been denied bail multiple times.
judgment_reason: The court refused to reconsider bail noting the petitioner's repeated applications despite consistent rejections, and emphasized his criminal antecedents.
summary: Patna High Court rejected the fourth bail request of Sonu Kumar in a robbery conspiracy case due to his prior criminal record and repeated applications.

case_title: Santosh Kumar Bhagat vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to recovery of stolen amount based on petitioner’s confession and involvement in a highway robbery case of ₹6,00,000.
facts: The informant was carrying ₹6,00,000 to deposit in a bank when he was looted by criminals. The FIR was filed against unknown persons, and later Santosh Kumar Bhagat was named during investigation. Based on his confessional statement, recovery of looted money was made from his possession, and he could not justify its ownership.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to an accused named during investigation and from whom stolen money was recovered based on confession.
judgment_reason: The Court denied bail due to the serious nature of the offence and the recovery of stolen cash based on the petitioner’s confession. However, it directed that trial should conclude within six months and allowed liberty to reapply if not concluded in that time.
summary: Patna High Court rejected bail to Santosh Kumar Bhagat in a highway robbery case, citing recovery of cash based on his confession and seriousness of offence.

case_title: Babu vs The State
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite initial rejection by Sessions Court on grounds of non-locality; no prior criminal record reported and charges related only to preparation for dacoity.
facts: On 12 October 2012, police patrolling near a railway underbridge in Mysore found seven individuals near a Tata Safari vehicle with clubs and iron rods. They were apprehended and disclosed that they had gathered from Maharashtra to commit dacoity. Weapons, cash, and mobile phones were seized, and the case was registered suo moto by the PSI.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when accused are apprehended while preparing for dacoity and are not residents of the local state.
judgment_reason: The Court held that mere non-local residency is not sufficient reason to deny bail, especially when there was no record of involvement in other cases and the alleged crime was in preparation stage. Bail was granted with conditions.
summary: Karnataka High Court granted bail to Babu and co-accused caught preparing for dacoity, noting they had no prior criminal record and locality alone cannot bar bail.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Mere non-local residence is not valid ground to deny bail', 'Preparation for dacoity without actual act does not preclude bail', 'Bail may be granted if no prior criminal record is found']

case_title: Sri Kirthiraj @ Kirthi vs State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to recovery of weapon and rope from the petitioner, and his involvement in a previous robbery case.
facts: The petitioner, accused No. 3, was arrested in connection with Crime No. 487/2013 for planning to commit dacoity. A weapon and rope were recovered from his possession. The charge sheet had been filed. He also had a previous robbery case registered in Jnanabharathi Police Station (Crime No. 124/2013).
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused has a prior robbery case and incriminating materials were recovered from his possession.
judgment_reason: The court rejected the bail citing the petitioner’s criminal background and recovery of materials suggesting preparation for dacoity, stating that his release may lead to repetition of similar offences.
summary: Karnataka High Court denied bail to Kirthiraj citing prior robbery case and recovery of weapon and rope, suggesting involvement in repeated similar offences.

case_title: Union Of India vs Shri Shiv Shanker Kesari
judge: Justice Dr. Arijit Pasayat & D.K. Jain
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted by High Court set aside; matter remanded for fresh consideration under Section 37 NDPS Act
facts: The respondent was found in alleged possession of approximately 400 kg of poppy straw. The Special Judge had denied bail, but the High Court granted it citing lack of exclusive possession and no criminal history. The Supreme Court held that the High Court failed to consider the stringent requirements under Section 37 of the NDPS Act.
legal_issues: Whether the High Court erred in granting bail without fulfilling the mandatory conditions under Section 37 of the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The Supreme Court held that the High Court failed to record findings on both conditions required under Section 37 — namely, reasonable grounds for believing the accused is not guilty and that he is not likely to commit any offence on bail.
summary: Supreme Court set aside bail granted to NDPS accused, ruling that High Court ignored mandatory Section 37 safeguards. Matter remanded for reconsideration after surrender.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Courts must satisfy dual conditions under Section 37 NDPS Act before granting bail', 'Reasonable grounds must mean more than prima facie grounds']

case_title: Ram Dayal vs Central Narcotic Bureau
judge: Justice R.C. Lahoti and S.K. Dubey
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected as the court ruled that Section 167(2) CrPC does not override Section 37 of the NDPS Act
facts: Ram Dayal was arrested on 8 August 1991 with 5,100 grams of opium found in an attache case while traveling by bus. He filed multiple bail applications, with the third one prompting a legal reference on the applicability of CrPC provisions to NDPS bail.
legal_issues: Whether filing a charge-sheet after 90 days entitles the accused to bail under CrPC; Whether non-compliance with Section 50 NDPS affects bail under Section 37.
judgment_reason: The court held that Section 37 of the NDPS Act overrides Section 167(2) CrPC for bail in narcotics cases. Procedural lapses like non-compliance with Section 50 do not by themselves justify bail unless they invalidate the jurisdiction.
summary: The High Court ruled that bail provisions under NDPS override CrPC defaults and that procedural lapses do not automatically justify bail.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 of NDPS Act overrides Section 167(2) CrPC for bail', 'Non-compliance with Section 50 NDPS Act must be bona fide and jurisdictionally significant to waive Section 37 restrictions', 'Procedural violations must cause prejudice to invalidate proceedings under NDPS']

case_title: Sardarsingh Nagsingh Rajput (Sisodia) vs State Of Gujarat
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Default bail under Section 167(2) CrPC and 36-A(1)(b) NDPS rejected due to overriding effect of Section 37 NDPS Act
facts: Sardarsingh was arrested with 1 kg of opium. His charge sheet was filed 44 days late, and he was not produced before a Special Court within 15 days as required under NDPS Act. He applied for default bail on these procedural grounds. Two other co-petitioners in connected matters had similar procedural delays related to Section 36-A(1)(b).
legal_issues: Whether procedural lapses like delay in filing chargesheet or not producing accused before Special Court within 15 days entitle default bail under NDPS Act, in light of Section 37 limitations.
