judgment_reason: The court held that procedural defaults do not override the stringent bail conditions under Section 37 of the NDPS Act. It reaffirmed that accused cannot claim default bail merely due to delays if the substantive conditions under Section 37 are not met.
summary: Gujarat High Court ruled that procedural lapses under Sections 167(2) CrPC and 36-A NDPS Act do not entitle default bail due to overriding effect of Section 37. Bail denied.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act overrides default bail provisions under Section 167(2) CrPC and Section 36-A(1)(b) NDPS', 'Magistrate must forward custody to Special Court within 15 days but failure does not mandate bail', 'Session Courts act as Special Courts under Section 36-D NDPS until formal Special Courts are constituted', 'Non-filing of FSL report or delay in charge sheet does not automatically invalidate custody']

case_title: Hari Sankaran vs Serious Fraud Investigation Office And
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted due to prolonged incarceration (5 years), severe health issues, and delay in trial commencement
facts: Hari Sankaran, a key accused in the IL&FS fraud case prosecuted by SFIO, was arrested in April 2019. The charges involved fraudulent financial activities under the Companies Act and IPC. The trial was delayed significantly, with cognizance taken only in late 2023, and over 60 witnesses listed. He remained the only accused still in custody and was suffering from multiple serious medical conditions.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged pre-trial incarceration and deteriorating health conditions justify bail despite statutory restrictions under Section 212(6) of the Companies Act, 2013.
judgment_reason: The court held that continued incarceration would violate Article 21 rights due to the accused's age, critical health conditions, and the unlikelihood of early trial completion. The bail was granted with conditions, invoking constitutional protection despite statutory embargoes.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Hari Sankaran citing 5-year incarceration, delayed trial, and severe health issues. Court harmonized constitutional rights with statutory restrictions.

case_title: Sher Bahadur Singh Son Of Shri Bhim vs State Of H.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted under Section 37 NDPS Act as recovered quantity was less than commercial quantity and trial was ongoing
facts: The accused, Sher Bahadur Singh, was allegedly found with 814 grams of cannabis (charas) near Shangan bridge during a police patrol. He was arrested after allegedly throwing a bag containing the substance upon seeing the police. Investigation was complete and the case was pending for prosecution evidence.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted under Section 37 of the NDPS Act when the recovered narcotics quantity is less than the commercial threshold.
judgment_reason: The court held that as the quantity recovered was below commercial quantity and the charge sheet had already been filed, the accused was entitled to bail. It emphasized that personal liberty under Article 21 and established bail jurisprudence favor granting bail under such circumstances.
summary: Bail granted to Sher Bahadur Singh in an NDPS case involving 814g charas. Court noted non-commercial quantity and upheld Article 21 protections.

case_title: Anil Kumar vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite commercial quantity due to prolonged incarceration (over 1 year), evidentiary limitations, and case-specific factors
facts: Anil Kumar was named as a co-accused in a narcotics case based on the disclosure statements of two arrested individuals who were found with 38 cough syrup bottles and 250 intoxicant tablets. He was arrested four months later and had phone records showing contact with the arrested accused. No drugs were recovered from his possession. He had two other FIRs involving NDPS sections.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged custody, lack of direct recovery, and limited evidentiary value of disclosure statements justify bail in a commercial quantity NDPS case under Section 37.
judgment_reason: The court held that despite commercial quantity being involved, no recovery was made from Anil Kumar directly, and his incarceration exceeded 1 year 2 months. Based on precedents where prolonged custody was deemed sufficient ground for bail, the court allowed bail with conditions.
summary: Anil Kumar was granted bail in a commercial NDPS case due to over one year of custody, lack of recovery, and weak evidence. Court applied liberty-focused precedents under Article 21.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration can override Section 37 NDPS restrictions', 'Disclosure statements alone are insufficient for continued detention without discovery', 'Right to speedy trial under Article 21 is paramount']

case_title: Sanjeev Kumar vs State Of Haryana
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite commercial quantity due to prolonged incarceration (1 year) and reliance on Supreme Court precedents favoring liberty
facts: Sanjeev Kumar was arrested based on a disclosure by co-accused Jaswinder Kaur, who was caught with 65 bottles of codeine-based cough syrup. During investigation, Sanjeev Kumar made disclosure leading to recovery of 60 more bottles and Rs. 10,000. He was in custody for over a year at the time of decision, and had no prior criminal record.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration in a commercial quantity NDPS case justifies bail under Article 21, despite Section 37 embargo.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail considering over a year of custody, lack of prior antecedents, and delay in trial, relying on multiple Supreme Court rulings that prolonged incarceration violates Article 21 rights.
summary: Sanjeev Kumar was granted bail in a codeine syrup NDPS case due to over a year in custody and pending trial. Court emphasized Article 21 rights over Section 37 bar.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration undermines Article 21', 'Bail permissible in commercial quantity NDPS cases based on liberty jurisprudence', 'Disclosure statements must be corroborated for sustained custody']

case_title: Maninder Pal Singh Sodhi vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite commercial quantity and prior NDPS cases due to 1 year 10 months incarceration and delayed trial
facts: Based on a chance recovery from co-accused Robin Masih, 600 tablets and 144 capsules of controlled medicines were recovered. Robin disclosed that the contraband belonged to Maninder Pal Singh Sodhi, who was arrested and remained in custody since June 2023. He has four prior NDPS cases, but most involved intermediate quantity. In the current case, the recovered quantity is commercial.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration (over 1 year and 10 months) justifies bail in a commercial quantity NDPS case despite multiple antecedents.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail noting that continued custody would violate Article 21, and that similarly placed individuals had been granted bail by the Supreme Court. Criminal antecedents alone were not considered sufficient to deny bail given the duration of custody.
summary: Punjab and Haryana High Court granted bail to Maninder Pal Singh Sodhi in a commercial NDPS case due to nearly two years in custody. Court relied on liberty jurisprudence and proportionality.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration overrides statutory embargo under Section 37 NDPS', 'Right to liberty under Article 21 must prevail when trial is delayed', 'Bail not to be denied solely on basis of past cases involving intermediate quantity']

case_title: Arif vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite commercial quantity due to prolonged custody of 1 year 8 months and constitutional protections under Article 21
facts: Arif was arrested on 13 June 2023 with 45 bottles of codeine-based Onerex cough syrup found during a chance recovery. The quantity seized was commercial, and the State claimed compliance with all statutory NDPS procedures. Arif had no prior criminal record and was in custody for 1 year and 8 months at the time of judgment.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration in a commercial quantity NDPS case justifies bail under Article 21 despite statutory bar under Section 37.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail citing multiple Supreme Court precedents allowing bail due to prolonged custody in commercial quantity NDPS cases. It emphasized that continued pre-trial incarceration violates Article 21 rights, especially when the trial is unlikely to conclude soon.
summary: Arif was granted bail in a codeine-based syrup NDPS case after 1 year and 8 months of custody. The court applied Supreme Court precedent on prolonged incarceration overriding Section 37.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration violates Article 21 even under NDPS Act', 'Section 37 NDPS Act cannot override fundamental right to liberty', 'Constitutional protection must prevail over procedural bars when trial is delayed']

case_title: Khushal Pal Alias Prince vs State Of Haryana
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite commercial quantity due to nearly 2 years of custody and applicability of Supreme Court precedents on prolonged incarceration
facts: On 13 March 2023, police seized 1800 tablets (225g) of Alprazolam from Khushal Pal @ Prince based on prior information. He was charged under Section 22(c) of the NDPS Act. The accused had no prior criminal record and had been in custody for nearly 1 year and 11 months at the time of the bail order.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration can justify bail under Article 21 even in cases involving commercial quantity under the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court emphasized that prolonged incarceration without conclusion of trial violates Article 21. It cited numerous Supreme Court judgments where similar bail was granted for extended pretrial custody in NDPS cases. Bail was thus allowed under constitutional principles overriding Section 37 restrictions.
summary: High Court granted bail to Khushal Pal in a commercial quantity NDPS case after nearly 2 years in custody. Court prioritized Article 21 rights and liberty jurisprudence.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged incarceration overrides Section 37 NDPS bar', 'Right to speedy trial and personal liberty under Article 21', 'Supreme Court precedents permit bail in long custody NDPS cases']

case_title: Syed vs State
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected under NDPS Act; court found no substantial change in circumstances or satisfaction of twin conditions under Section 37
facts: The applicant was allegedly involved in a narcotics case involving concealment of drugs in car compartments. The prosecution relied on statements from witnesses Jalaluddin (who died) and Salim (who turned hostile), and a confessional statement by a co-accused. The applicant had been in jail for over six years and sought bail on grounds of parity and changed circumstances.
legal_issues: Whether hostile witnesses and prolonged incarceration constitute a change in circumstance sufficient to override Section 37 of the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court held that the statutory mandate of Section 37 was not met as the accused did not establish reasonable grounds for believing he was not guilty or that he would not reoffend. The court emphasized the seriousness of narcotic offenses and societal impact, finding no sufficient change in circumstances to justify bail.
summary: Gujarat High Court denied bail to Syed Babar Chisty in a long-pending NDPS case, citing lack of compliance with Section 37's mandatory conditions despite long incarceration.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Twin conditions under Section 37 NDPS must be satisfied for bail', 'Hostile witnesses do not automatically weaken prosecution', 'Long incarceration not sufficient alone to override Section 37']

case_title: Rohan Gawans vs Union Of India And Anr
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail granted despite NDPS Section 37 embargo; court found lack of recovery from accused and parity with co-accused already released on bail
facts: Rohan Gawans was arrested in 2017 in connection with an NDPS case involving seizure of 25 kg of Mephedrone allegedly linked to his factory, M/s Rohan Chemicals. The case relied on statements under Section 67 NDPS Act and indirect links through co-accused. No contraband was recovered from him personally, and multiple co-accused had already been granted bail.
legal_issues: Whether statements under Section 67 NDPS and circumstantial links without recovery are sufficient to deny bail under Section 37 of the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court held that the case was primarily based on Section 67 statements without corroborative evidence, and noted parity with co-accused already on bail. It ruled that continued incarceration was unwarranted under Article 21, especially as no direct recovery was made from the accused.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Rohan Gawans in an NDPS case involving indirect allegations and no personal recovery. Court emphasized Article 21 and parity.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail can be granted under NDPS despite Section 37 if no recovery and only 67 statements exist', 'Article 21 mandates personal liberty when evidence is weak or indirect', 'Parity with co-accused granted bail is a valid ground']

case_title: Kirta Ram vs State Of Rajasthan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Statutory bail under Section 167(2) CrPC read with Section 36A(4) NDPS Act rejected due to valid extension of time for chargesheet
facts: Kirta Ram was arrested for transporting 2 quintals and 17 kg of poppy husk. During a police chase, he allegedly fired at constable Ugma Ram, injuring him. A country-made pistol and 7 live cartridges were recovered from the vehicle. The FIR was lodged by the SHO and charge-sheet was eventually filed after judicial extensions.
legal_issues: Whether the accused is entitled to statutory bail under Section 167(2) CrPC read with Section 36A(4) NDPS Act due to alleged delay in filing chargesheet.
judgment_reason: The court found that the prosecution had applied for and was granted multiple judicial extensions for filing the chargesheet before the accused applied for bail. Relying on Supreme Court precedent, the court ruled that no statutory right to bail had accrued to the accused.
summary: Kirta Ram's statutory bail plea was rejected. The court upheld judicial extensions for filing chargesheet in a narcotics and firing case.

case_title: Surendra Bhati vs State Of Rajasthan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Bail rejected due to recovery of commercial quantity of narcotics and bar under Section 37 NDPS Act
facts: On 15.06.2021, police intercepted a vehicle driven by Surendra Bhati with co-accused Vimal Kumar Bairva. Upon search, 7.5 kg of poppy juice was recovered from the vehicle. Both were arrested and charge-sheeted under the NDPS Act.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted despite the recovery of a commercial quantity of narcotic substance, considering the bar under Section 37 of the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court held that the recovery of 7.5 kg of opium constituted a commercial quantity, invoking the embargo under Section 37 of the NDPS Act. The minor discrepancies in memos were not sufficient to grant bail at this stage. Thus, bail was denied.
summary: Bail was denied to the accused due to commercial quantity of opium recovered. Section 37 NDPS Act was invoked to bar bail.

case_title: Sukhchain Singh vs State Of Rajasthan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Second regular bail granted after initial rejection; court found no conscious possession and no prior criminal antecedents
facts: The petitioner was arrested after being found seated in the back seat of a car where 39,500 tablets of Tramadol Hydrochloride were recovered. The co-accused were allegedly involved in procurement and transportation of the contraband. The prosecution alleged conscious possession, but defense highlighted lack of knowledge and role.
legal_issues: Whether the petitioner had conscious possession of contraband under the NDPS Act and whether Section 37 conditions were satisfied.
judgment_reason: The court found that there was no material indicating the petitioner's direct involvement or knowledge of the contraband. Statements of the co-accused and investigating officer supported the claim of no conscious possession. The petitioner had no prior record and had been in custody since 2021.
summary: Regular bail granted to Sukhchain Singh under NDPS Act due to lack of evidence of conscious possession. Court found no prior antecedents and prolonged custody.

case_title: Vimal Kumar Bairva vs State Of Rajasthan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to recovery of 7.5 kg opium and lack of satisfaction under Section 37 NDPS Act
facts: On 15.06.2021, police intercepted a vehicle driven by Surendra Singh Bhati with Vimal Kumar Bairva seated beside him. Upon search, 7.5 kg of opium was recovered. Both accused were arrested and charge-sheeted under NDPS Act provisions.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a case involving commercial quantity of opium under the embargo of Section 37 NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court held that recovery of commercial quantity (7.5 kg opium) creates a statutory bar under Section 37 NDPS Act and the defense failed to establish grounds for bail. Minor procedural discrepancies did not justify bail.
summary: Bail application of Vimal Kumar Bairva rejected due to commercial quantity recovery under NDPS Act. Court cited statutory restrictions under Section 37.

case_title: Jasvinder Singh vs State Of Himachal Pradesh
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted despite recovery of intermediate quantity of Charas and one prior IPC case; court cited presumption of innocence and COVID delays
facts: On 5.8.2020, police stopped a mini truck and recovered 102 grams of Charas from under the seat, allegedly in possession of driver Jasvinder Singh. The accused attempted to flee and was arrested. He has been in custody since then.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail should be granted for intermediate quantity under NDPS Act, especially when one prior IPC case exists against the accused.
judgment_reason: The court noted that the quantity recovered was intermediate and the accused was a first-time NDPS offender. The court emphasized the presumption of innocence, lack of recovery pending, and prolonged custody due to COVID-19. Bail was granted with stringent conditions.
summary: Regular bail granted to Jasvinder Singh for alleged possession of intermediate quantity of Charas. Court cited COVID delay, presumption of innocence, and no NDPS antecedents.

case_title: Mustakim vs State Of H.P
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after nearly 3 years of pre-trial detention; court cited delay in trial and prolonged incarceration despite commercial quantity
facts: Mustakim was accused in an NDPS case involving the transportation of poppy-straw. Although no contraband was found in his possession, the prosecution alleged financial transactions linked him to co-accused who transported over 450 kg of poppy-straw. He had prior NDPS cases pending.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged pre-trial detention and lack of direct recovery justify bail under NDPS despite Section 37 embargo.
judgment_reason: The court considered that Mustakim had been in custody for nearly 3 years, the trial had not commenced, and there was no direct recovery from him. Relying on Supreme Court precedents, the court emphasized that prolonged incarceration violates Article 21.
summary: Mustakim was granted regular bail in an NDPS case involving commercial quantity after 3 years of detention. The court stressed delay in trial and absence of direct recovery.

case_title: Deepak Rawat vs. State Of H.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Interim bail rejected as the court held that the accused failed to satisfy Section 37 NDPS Act requirements; Codeine Phosphate held to be a manufactured drug
facts: On 30.11.2023, 50 bottles of Codeine Phosphate-based cough syrup were seized from Pankaj Kumar, who named Deepak Rawat as the seller. Bank records confirmed a payment of ₹9,600 from the main accused to Deepak Rawat. Deepak claimed to be a licensed drug dealer and sought interim bail during pendency of reference to a larger bench on whether such cough syrups are covered under NDPS Act.
legal_issues: Whether sale of Codeine Phosphate syrup by a licensed dealer constitutes an NDPS offence, and whether interim bail is permissible pending reference to a larger bench on this issue.
judgment_reason: The court held that Codeine Phosphate falls under 'manufactured drug' per current binding precedents. It rejected interim bail as the accused could not meet Section 37 NDPS Act conditions and the law on the subject remains settled despite the reference.
summary: Interim bail was denied to Deepak Rawat in a Codeine Phosphate syrup case under NDPS Act. Court held existing law includes such drugs and rigors of Section 37 apply.

case_title: Sudhir Sharma vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted despite multiple prior cases; court noted absence from crime scene and that charge-sheet had been filed
facts: Sudhir Sharma was accused of participating in the murder of the informant’s son by firearm, allegedly in revenge for a prior killing. He was not present at the scene of the shooting, and the police had already filed a charge-sheet.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a murder case where the accused has prior cases but was not present at the scene and charge-sheet has been submitted.
judgment_reason: The court observed that the petitioner was not present at the location where the shooting occurred. Despite criminal antecedents, the court granted bail considering completed investigation and parity with co-accused already granted bail.
summary: Sudhir Sharma was granted regular bail in a murder case due to lack of presence at crime scene and completed investigation. Court noted co-accused with graver allegations had already received bail.

case_title: Ujjwal Kumar @ Ujjawal Jordan vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted despite 15 prior cases; court noted absence from crime scene and parity with co-accused already granted bail
facts: Ujjwal Kumar was accused of involvement in the murder of the informant’s son by firearm, allegedly arising from past enmities. He was not present at the scene of the firing. Investigation was complete and charge-sheet had been submitted. The informant had a hostile history with the petitioner.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a murder case where the accused has multiple prior cases but was not present at the crime scene and investigation is complete.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail noting the petitioner was not at the scene of the shooting, the investigation was complete, and co-accused with more serious allegations had already been granted bail.
summary: Ujjwal Kumar was granted regular bail in a murder case due to non-presence at the crime scene and completed investigation. The court emphasized parity with co-accused already granted bail.

case_title: Swapnil Navnath Naiknavare vs The State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted; court noted lack of criminal antecedents and parity with co-accused already granted bail
facts: The accused, a compounder, allegedly connived with co-accused to kidnap the complainant’s son and demand ₹20 lakh ransom. The child was unharmed and returned safely. The FIR was filed on November 25, 2018, and the applicant was arrested the same day.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted to an accused in a kidnapping-for-ransom case when co-accused are already granted bail and there are no prior criminal antecedents.
judgment_reason: The court observed the applicant had no prior criminal history, charge-sheet was filed, and co-accused who committed the abduction were already released on bail. Bail was granted with conditions to report monthly to police and attend trial.
summary: Swapnil Naiknavare was granted regular bail in a kidnapping-for-ransom case due to lack of criminal antecedents and parity with co-accused already released on bail.

case_title: Gurpreet Singh @ Gopi @ Panch vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after nearly 20 months of custody; court noted delay in trial and parity with co-accused already on bail
facts: On 20.08.2020, a newborn male child was abducted from Civil Hospital, Jalandhar. CCTV footage showed Gurpreet Singh @ Gopi and a co-accused taking the child in a car. Investigation revealed the child was handed over to others as part of an illegal adoption for money. The child was recovered safely.
legal_issues: Whether regular bail can be granted in a child trafficking/kidnapping case when the accused has no prior record, has been in prolonged custody, and co-accused are already on bail.
judgment_reason: The court found that the petitioner had no criminal history, was not named in the FIR, and had been in custody since August 2020. Co-accused, including those with greater alleged involvement, had already been granted bail. Trial had not progressed significantly.
summary: Gurpreet Singh @ Gopi was granted regular bail in a kidnapping case due to prolonged custody and parity with co-accused already released on bail. Court noted trial delays and lack of prior offenses.

case_title: Narendra Prajapati vs Union Of India
court: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Jabalpur Bench
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail denied due to applicant's role as main beneficiary in Rs. 80 crore bank fraud and 20 similar prior cases
facts: Narendra Prajapati, acting as guarantor, was accused of conspiring with bank officials and others to fraudulently secure and misuse a ₹4 crore loan under forged documentation and diverted funds. Investigations revealed multiple similar frauds connected to him, with the bulk of loan funds routed to entities under his control.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted to the main accused in a large-scale bank fraud case with multiple prior similar offenses and misuse of funds.
judgment_reason: The court held that the applicant was the primary conspirator and beneficiary of the fraudulent loan scheme. Given the gravity, scale of fraud (₹80 crore), and multiple similar offenses, bail was denied despite prolonged custody.
summary: Bail was denied to Narendra Prajapati in a ₹4 crore bank fraud case. The court cited his central role and multiple similar offenses as grounds for rejection.

case_title: CBI Hyderabad vs Subramani Gopalakrishnan and Anr
judge: Justice P. Sathasivam, Justice B.S. Chauhan
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Supreme Court cancelled bail granted by High Court due to accused's key role in corporate financial fraud of Satyam Computers
facts: Subramani Gopalakrishnan, a partner at Price Waterhouse, served as statutory auditor of Satyam Computer Services Ltd. (SCSL) during the years the company falsified accounts, inflating cash and bank balances and misleading shareholders. He was accused of failing to perform due diligence and misrepresenting financial statements, contributing to one of India's largest corporate frauds.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be cancelled for an external auditor allegedly complicit in a large-scale corporate fraud involving falsified financial reporting.
judgment_reason: The Supreme Court held that due to the accused's pivotal role in inflating assets over several years, risk of witness influence, and ongoing trial under strict timeline, the High Court erred in granting bail. His long association and failure to detect or report discrepancies made his conduct central to the conspiracy.
summary: The Supreme Court cancelled the bail of Subramani Gopalakrishnan, auditor in the Satyam scam, citing his long-standing role in falsifying financial records and risk to fair trial.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail cancellation due to role in conspiracy and influence on witnesses', 'Difference in bail jurisprudence between similarly placed co-accused when factual roles differ', 'Expeditious trial as a ground to deny bail']

case_title: The State Of Maharashtra vs Shri Ananda Tukaram Akale and Tasgaon Co-op Bank
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Anticipatory bail cancelled due to serious financial fraud involving public funds; court directed accused to surrender and apply for regular bail
facts: Ananda Tukaram Akale, a cement agency operator, was accused of defrauding the Tasgaon Co-operative Bank through manipulated deposit slips and ledger entries, causing financial discrepancies. The alleged fraud involved unexplained differences between bank deposit slips, passbooks, and journal entries, pointing to collusion with bank officials.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail should be cancelled when custodial interrogation is necessary for recovering forged documents and exposing conspiracy involving public funds.
judgment_reason: The court found multiple inconsistencies between deposit slips and account books. It held that custodial interrogation was necessary to recover documents and investigate potential collusion. Also criticized unlimited anticipatory bail granted without considering investigation needs.
summary: Bombay High Court cancelled anticipatory bail of Ananda Tukaram Akale in a co-operative bank fraud case, citing custodial interrogation needs and financial irregularities. Directed him to surrender and apply for regular bail.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Anticipatory bail should be time-limited and not bypass regular court procedures', 'Custodial interrogation can be essential in economic offenses', 'Grant of bail must balance individual liberty with investigative needs']

case_title: Islamuddin @ Chottey vs State Of Delhi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Interim bail denied under Section 37 NDPS Act despite humanitarian grounds due to legislative bar on bail without meeting dual conditions
facts: Islamuddin, facing trial under Sections 21/61/85 of the NDPS Act, applied for interim bail claiming his wife required surgery and needed his assistance. The prosecution opposed the plea, citing his criminal history of 21 prior cases and NDPS-related offenses. The court had previously denied regular bail.
legal_issues: Whether interim bail can be granted under humanitarian grounds to an accused under NDPS Act when Section 37's twin conditions are not met.
judgment_reason: The court held that under Section 37 of the NDPS Act, no bail (including interim bail) can be granted unless the twin conditions are met—proof of innocence and assurance against reoffending. Humanitarian concerns like illness of a spouse are not grounds recognized under the statute.
summary: Delhi High Court denied interim bail to Islamuddin, citing the strict bar under Section 37 NDPS Act. Court ruled that humanitarian reasons cannot override statutory bail limitations.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act overrides CrPC and restricts all forms of bail unless strict conditions are met', 'Humanitarian grounds cannot justify interim bail under NDPS without satisfying statutory tests', 'Section 482 CrPC cannot be invoked to circumvent NDPS bail limitations']

case_title: Edwin Emeka Igbokwe vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail denied under Section 37 NDPS Act due to commercial quantity, organized trafficking operation, and foreign national status of accused
facts: Edwin Emeka Igbokwe, a Nigerian national, was implicated after 575 grams of heroin was found hidden in shock absorbers in a parcel destined for Spain. He was linked through statements of co-accused Stanley, call detail records, and recovery of shock absorber tools and packaging material from his residence. He was arrested in 2017 and remained in judicial custody.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted to a foreign national accused in a commercial quantity NDPS case based on circumstantial evidence and prolonged detention.
judgment_reason: The court held that the recovery of materials linked to concealment of narcotics, CDR evidence, and the accused’s foreign nationality justified denial of bail. It emphasized Section 37 NDPS Act’s mandatory twin conditions and found the petitioner failed to meet them.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Edwin Igbokwe in a commercial quantity heroin case, citing organized concealment, evidence from his home, and NDPS Section 37 bar.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Twin conditions under Section 37 NDPS Act apply strictly to commercial quantity cases', 'Bail not to be granted unless court believes accused is not guilty and won’t reoffend', 'Foreign nationality and flight risk weigh against granting bail']

case_title: Kapil Dev vs The State
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after key prosecution witness turned hostile and court observed significant doubts about the recovery of contraband
facts: Kapil Dev was accused of being found in possession of 500 grams of heroin. His first bail application was denied due to commercial quantity. In the second application, the independent public witness denied witnessing any recovery, and discrepancies were found in police documents. The court found these developments crucial enough to reassess bail.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted under NDPS Act when prosecution's independent witness turns hostile and documentary inconsistencies are revealed.
judgment_reason: The court held that the independent public witness denying recovery and inconsistencies in documentary evidence cast doubt on the prosecution's case. Given no criminal antecedents and low likelihood of reoffending, bail was granted despite NDPS Section 37 bar.
summary: Kapil Dev was granted bail under NDPS despite commercial quantity, as the public witness turned hostile and serious procedural doubts arose about the recovery.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Second bail application maintainable if facts change significantly', 'Section 37 NDPS Act requires satisfaction that accused may not be convicted', 'Hostile witness and document tampering justify reevaluation of bail denial']

case_title: Asante Pinket Owusu vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 5 years of incarceration; court held that Section 37 NDPS Act does not apply to controlled substances like ephedrine
facts: Asante Pinket Owusu, a foreign national, was intercepted at Hazrat Nizamuddin Railway Station with 16.4 kg of ephedrine hydrochloride concealed in quilts. She admitted in a voluntary statement to involvement in trafficking. Charges were framed in 2019 under Sections 9A and 25A of the NDPS Act. The trial had progressed slowly, and she had been in custody since November 2018.
legal_issues: Whether Section 37 NDPS applies to controlled substances like ephedrine; whether prolonged incarceration and procedural violations justify bail despite serious charges.
judgment_reason: The court ruled that Section 37 NDPS does not apply to controlled substances, which do not have a 'commercial quantity' threshold. Given the applicant's 5-year detention, slow trial, and procedural irregularities in sampling, bail was granted with strict conditions and embassy assurance requirements.
summary: Delhi High Court granted regular bail to Asante Pinket Owusu after 5 years in custody, holding that Section 37 NDPS does not apply to controlled substances like ephedrine.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act does not apply to controlled substances under Sections 9A and 25A', 'Prolonged pre-trial detention can justify bail in NDPS cases not involving narcotic drugs or psychotropic substances', 'Procedural lapses in sampling under Standing Order 1/88 are material to bail decisions', 'Foreign nationals may be granted bail subject to embassy assurance and strict conditions']

case_title: Girish Bharti vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to commercial quantity ketamine recovery and electronic evidence linking accused to organized drug trafficking network
facts: On 15.09.2023, a parcel containing 677 grams of ketamine was intercepted at DHL, New Delhi. The parcel was linked to Girish Bharti through co-accused’s disclosure, recovered packing materials, photocopies of fake IDs, and mobile phone data. Bharti was arrested at his residence where similar materials and ₹5.84 lakh in cash were found. Phone data showed communications with co-accused and parcel tracking.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a commercial quantity NDPS case when recovery is indirect but supported by digital and circumstantial evidence.
judgment_reason: The court held that Section 37 NDPS Act applied due to commercial quantity and found sufficient evidence—co-accused's statements, recovered materials, and call records—indicating the petitioner's guilt. Bail was denied due to risk of reoffending and flight.
summary: Delhi High Court rejected Girish Bharti’s bail plea in a ketamine trafficking case, citing commercial quantity and strong digital evidence linking him to the offence.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS imposes dual conditions for bail in commercial quantity cases', '‘Reasonable grounds’ under NDPS means substantial probability beyond prima facie view', 'Digital and circumstantial evidence can establish sufficient ground for bail denial']

case_title: Muhsin Ali vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected under Section 37 NDPS Act due to role in heroin trafficking syndicate and recovery of commercial quantity at his instance
facts: Muhsin Ali was arrested after 5 grams of heroin were recovered from a hotel room where he stayed with co-accused. His disclosure led to the interception of a 980g heroin parcel. He was linked to multiple co-accused involved in trafficking via courier. Prosecution cited WhatsApp chats, co-accused statements, and ID recoveries as evidence.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when the accused is part of a larger drug syndicate and commercial quantity is recovered based on his disclosure.
judgment_reason: The court held that Muhsin Ali’s involvement in a heroin trafficking network and the discovery of 980g heroin on his disclosure triggered Section 37 NDPS Act. His role was distinct from co-accused granted bail, and Section 27 Evidence Act justified admissibility of his disclosure. Bail was denied due to insufficient grounds of innocence and risk of reoffending.
summary: Delhi High Court rejected Muhsin Ali’s bail in a commercial quantity heroin case, citing syndicate links and recovery of contraband on his disclosure.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS imposes twin conditions for bail in commercial quantity cases', 'Disclosure leading to recovery is admissible under Section 27 Evidence Act', 'Ground of parity not available where co-accused are not involved in larger conspiracy']

case_title: Abul Kalam @ Sultan vs State (NCT Of Delhi)
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to strong digital evidence, CDRs, and statements linking petitioner to inter-State heroin trafficking syndicate
facts: Abul Kalam was arrested following the interception of 10 kg heroin from two accused who named him as a syndicate member. He was later traced and arrested in West Bengal. While no contraband was recovered from him directly, ₹1.29 lakh cash was found. CDRs and transcripts showed regular contact with co-accused and discussions related to drug supply.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted under NDPS Act when the accused is implicated through CDRs, disclosures, and syndicate-level conspiracy despite no direct recovery.
judgment_reason: The court found that CDRs and transcripts revealed active coordination with co-accused in a heroin trafficking syndicate. The use of fictitious identities for SIMs and coded drug-related communication undermined the petitioner's claim of innocence. Section 37 NDPS conditions were not satisfied.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Abul Kalam in a heroin trafficking case, citing CDR and transcript evidence linking him to a drug syndicate and non-compliance with NDPS Section 37.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act requires twin satisfaction: not guilty and unlikely to reoffend', 'Reasonable grounds must be based on substantial probable cause, not prima facie view', 'Surveillance-based transcripts and digital trail can be sufficient for bail denial']

case_title: Sheela vs State Govt. Of NCT Of Delhi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected as applicant was held to be in conscious possession of commercial quantity of Ganja while travelling with co-accused
facts: Sheela was apprehended along with co-accused Vinod and Iqbal while travelling in an auto-rickshaw. Two bags containing a total of 38.33 kg of Ganja were recovered—14.13 kg near Sheela and 24.20 kg near Vinod. The prosecution alleged conspiracy supported by mobile call records. All three were charged under Section 20(C)/29 of the NDPS Act.
legal_issues: Whether Sheela can be granted bail under NDPS Act when she was in joint conscious possession of commercial quantity while travelling with co-accused in the same vehicle.
judgment_reason: The court held that since the accused were jointly travelling in the same vehicle and in possession of contraband exceeding the commercial quantity threshold, Section 37 NDPS Act applied. Telephonic records and joint custody of Ganja supported constructive possession and conspiracy.
summary: Delhi High Court denied regular bail to Sheela under NDPS Act, citing joint conscious possession of commercial quantity of Ganja and failure to meet Section 37 conditions.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS imposes strict twin conditions for bail in commercial quantity cases', 'Constructive possession applies when accused jointly travel with contraband', 'Section 50 NDPS does not apply when recovery is not from the person', 'Delay in Section 52A compliance not sufficient ground for bail absent other factors']

case_title: Gopal Sen vs The State (Govt. Of NCT Of Delhi)
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected under Section 37 NDPS due to involvement in conspiracy to supply commercial quantity heroin, despite no direct recovery from petitioner
facts: Based on a tip-off, narcotics officers intercepted a scooter carrying Sunil @ Naniya and Gopal Sen. Sunil was driving and Gopal was the pillion rider. 8 kg of heroin was recovered from Sunil's bag. Gopal was identified by the informer as the trader supplying the narcotics. No recovery was made directly from Gopal.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused is apprehended with a co-accused in possession of commercial quantity of heroin, but no recovery is made from the accused personally.
judgment_reason: The court held that Gopal Sen’s presence as pillion rider and identification as the trader from whom heroin was being sourced pointed to his role in a conspiracy under Section 29 NDPS. Given the commercial quantity involved, the court found no reasonable ground to believe that the petitioner was not guilty, as required under Section 37 NDPS Act.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Gopal Sen in a heroin trafficking case, citing his alleged conspiracy role and failure to satisfy the twin conditions of Section 37 NDPS Act.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS bars bail unless twin conditions of non-guilt and no future offence are satisfied', 'Presence with co-accused and identification as supplier sufficient to invoke Section 29 NDPS', 'Bail may be harder than acquittal in NDPS commercial quantity cases']

case_title: Ram Kishan vs State Of NCT Of Delhi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to commercial quantity Charas recovery and non-fulfillment of Section 37 NDPS conditions despite 6 years of incarceration
facts: Ram Kishan was arrested on 22.07.2016 at Ghata Masjid Road with 1.5 kg of Charas. He was charged under Section 20(ii)(c) of the NDPS Act. Defense raised concerns over absence of public witnesses and procedural lapses in FSL submission. The petitioner remained in custody for over 6 years, with trial delays partly due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration and procedural irregularities justify bail in NDPS cases involving commercial quantity under Section 37 NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court noted that 1.5 kg Charas qualifies as commercial quantity and that most prosecution witnesses had been examined. Citing Supreme Court precedent in NCB vs. Mohit Aggarwal, the court held that long custody alone does not override the twin conditions of Section 37 NDPS Act, which the petitioner failed to meet.
summary: Delhi High Court denied regular bail to Ram Kishan for 1.5 kg Charas recovery, holding that prolonged custody does not negate the strict Section 37 NDPS bail limitations.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS requires reasonable belief of non-guilt and low risk of reoffending', 'Prolonged incarceration is not an independent ground to override NDPS bail bar', 'Compliance with procedural safeguards does not negate substantive recovery']

case_title: Ved Prakash @ Mistri vs The State (NCT Of Delhi)
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to recovery of commercial quantity heroin from co-accused and voice match evidence implicating petitioner under Section 29 NDPS Act
facts: Ved Prakash was arrested based on the disclosure of co-accused Ram Pal, who was caught with 1 kg heroin. Ram Pal claimed he purchased the heroin from Ved Prakash. Voice samples of both accused were sent to FSL, and expert analysis indicated a probable match. No contraband was found on Ved Prakash himself.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted under NDPS Act when recovery is from co-accused and link to petitioner is based on disclosure and voice sample evidence, in a commercial quantity case.
judgment_reason: The court held that the petitioner failed to establish reasonable grounds for believing he was not guilty, as required by Section 37 NDPS Act. Given the commercial quantity involved and corroborative voice sample analysis, bail was denied despite no direct recovery from the petitioner.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Ved Prakash in a heroin case, citing commercial quantity, conspiracy under Section 29 NDPS, and voice evidence linking him to the contraband.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act bars bail unless court is satisfied of non-guilt and low risk of reoffending', 'Indirect evidence such as co-accused disclosure and voice match can support conspiracy charges', 'Absence of recovery from accused does not automatically entitle bail if conspiracy is alleged']

case_title: Madan Lama vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to recovery of 475g charas and accused's status as non-resident foreign national with flight risk
facts: On 18.12.2020, Madan Lama, a Nepali national, was apprehended near East of Kailash Metro Station with 46 packets of charas totaling 475 grams. He was caught handing over one packet to co-accused Haresh Rawal in exchange for money. The NCB arrested both individuals and seized the contraband. Lama admitted to supplying drugs and was charged under Sections 8, 20(b), and 29 of the NDPS Act.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted in a narcotics case involving intermediate quantity where the accused is a foreign national with no roots in India and is alleged to be a supplier.
judgment_reason: The court rejected bail citing that the petitioner, as a foreign national with no local roots, posed a flight risk. Although the quantity was intermediate, the petitioner’s role as a supplier, risk of reoffending, and potential for absconding outweighed parity arguments with co-accused who possessed only a small quantity.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Madan Lama in a charas trafficking case, citing his foreign nationality, role as supplier, and risk of absconding despite intermediate quantity involved.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Even in intermediate quantity NDPS cases, role and flight risk are crucial to bail', 'Section 37 NDPS does not apply to intermediate quantity, but gravity of offence still matters', 'Parity does not apply where factual roles and quantity differ', 'Foreign nationality and lack of roots are valid grounds to deny bail']

case_title: Ravi Kant Prabhakar vs State Govt Of NCT Of Delhi
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to pending investigation, unarrested co-accused, and admission of intent to defraud business partner using forged coupons
facts: Ravi Kant Prabhakar, a hotel industry professional, allegedly conspired to defraud Apni Rasoi Pvt. Ltd. after business disputes arose. He created a scheme with a co-accused to issue fake discount coupons through Add India Advertising without the complainant's consent, intending to cause massive losses to the company while earning a personal commission. He admitted his role during police interrogation.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted in a commercial cheating and forgery case where the accused admits to fraudulent intent and key co-accused remains unarrested.
judgment_reason: The court noted that the investigation was incomplete, the co-accused was yet to be arrested, and the petitioner had confessed to creating and distributing forged coupons to harm the complainant’s business. Given these factors and potential for tampering with evidence, bail was denied.
summary: Delhi High Court denied bail to Ravi Kant Prabhakar in a fraud case involving forged coupons and intent to defraud Apni Rasoi, citing ongoing investigation and confessed conspiracy.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Bail can be denied if investigation is pending and co-accused is absconding', 'Confession indicating fraudulent intent weighs against granting bail', 'Documentary nature of evidence does not alone justify release when fraud is ongoing or systemic']

case_title: Premwati vs Narcotics Control Bureau
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected in third attempt despite delay in trial and petitioner’s medical condition; court directed expedited trial instead
facts: Premwati was arrested along with her husband for allegedly delivering 1 kg of heroin to co-accused Usha, who was later found with another 2 kg of heroin. Usha identified them through photographs. No direct recovery was made from Premwati. Her counsel argued she merely accompanied her husband and pointed to her health issues and repeated interim bail compliance.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted on grounds of delay in trial, petitioner’s health, and lack of direct recovery in a case involving commercial quantity of narcotics.
judgment_reason: The court acknowledged systemic delays in prosecution and NCB's non-cooperation but declined bail due to previous rejections and the commercial quantity involved. Instead, it directed the trial court to expedite proceedings and stated that the petitioner could apply again if delays persisted.
summary: Delhi High Court rejected Premwati’s third bail plea in a heroin case, despite trial delays and medical grounds, but ordered expedited trial and allowed liberty to reapply if delays continued.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Repeated bail rejection narrows scope of reconsideration absent change in circumstance', 'Trial delay may warrant bail if prosecution is responsible, especially under Article 21', 'Even non-recovery accused in NDPS commercial quantity cases face Section 37 bar', 'Medical condition and compliance with interim bail may be mitigating but not determinative']

case_title: Dipesh Uttam Sawant vs Union Of India
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted; court held Section 27A and commercial quantity NDPS charges not made out as accused was merely acting under instructions of employer with no possession or intent to traffic
facts: Dipesh Sawant, an employee of actor Sushant Singh Rajput, was arrested under NDPS Act based on statements linking him to procurement of Ganja and Charas for Sushant and Rhea Chakraborty via other accused. No contraband was recovered from him. The prosecution invoked Section 29 (conspiracy) and Section 27A (financing illicit traffic). He was alleged to have received drugs on instructions of others but was not a consumer or dealer himself.
legal_issues: Whether a domestic employee acting on instructions of employer can be denied bail under Section 27A or Section 29 NDPS without evidence of trafficking, possession, or commercial quantity.
judgment_reason: The court held that there was no recovery from the applicant, and he merely acted at the behest of others without dealing in or possessing commercial quantity. Section 27A was not applicable, and Section 37 NDPS did not bar bail. The court emphasized absence of profit motive or control over contraband.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Dipesh Sawant, citing lack of recovery, absence of trafficking intent, and his subordinate role under instructions of employer Sushant Singh Rajput.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 27A NDPS requires evidence of financing or harboring drug offenses', "Mere procurement on employer's instruction does not establish criminal conspiracy under Section 29", 'Commercial quantity not established, hence Section 37 NDPS not attracted', 'Servant not in possession unless control over contraband is proved']

case_title: Showik Chakraborty vs Union Of India And Anr
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected under NDPS Act due to evidence of links with multiple drug dealers and role in facilitating drug procurement for others including financial transactions
facts: Showik Chakraborty was arrested by the Narcotics Control Bureau in September 2020 in a case related to the drug angle arising from the Sushant Singh Rajput death investigation. He was accused of procuring drugs through a network involving several co-accused and arranging payments through various means. The case involved recovery of commercial quantity LSD from a linked co-accused and digital evidence of drug facilitation.
legal_issues: Whether Showik Chakraborty's role in a conspiracy for procurement and payment for drugs invoked the rigors of Section 37 NDPS Act and justified denial of bail at the preliminary stage of investigation.
judgment_reason: The court found sufficient prima facie material showing Showik's involvement in a drug syndicate, including coordination, facilitation, and monetary transactions with multiple accused. The court held that Section 37 NDPS conditions were not satisfied and refused to grant bail while investigation was ongoing.
summary: Bombay High Court denied bail to Showik Chakraborty in an NDPS case, citing his involvement in drug procurement, monetary links, and connections with a trafficking network.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS applies in conspiracy cases involving commercial quantity, even without personal recovery', 'Participation in a drug trafficking network through facilitation and payment qualifies as abetment under Section 29 NDPS', 'Preliminary stage of investigation is a valid ground to deny bail when links to syndicate are evident']

case_title: Samuel Miranda S/O Marshal Miranda vs Union Of India And Anr
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted; court held no recovery from applicant and insufficient material to connect him with commercial quantity or Section 27A NDPS charge
facts: Samuel Miranda, house-help of actor Sushant Singh Rajput, was arrested under multiple NDPS sections based on statements of co-accused linking him to procurement of Ganja and Charas for the late actor. No contraband was recovered from him. He was alleged to have received deliveries on instructions from Showik Chakraborty and paid using Rhea Chakraborty’s debit card.
legal_issues: Whether Samuel Miranda’s role as a house-help acting under employer's instructions without direct recovery or profit involvement attracted Section 27A or commercial quantity under NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The court held that Section 27A NDPS was not attracted and there was no evidence of commercial quantity or personal possession. His role was limited to that of a subordinate following instructions without control over contraband. Bail was granted with strict conditions.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Samuel Miranda in an NDPS case, citing no recovery, subordinate role, and absence of commercial quantity or Section 27A applicability.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 27A NDPS not applicable in absence of evidence of financing or harboring', 'Servants acting on employer’s instructions not in possession without control over contraband', 'No application of Section 37 NDPS without commercial quantity', 'Change in circumstance such as lack of material can justify bail']

case_title: Imran Ilyas Dalla vs State Of Maharashtra Through PS In-Charge
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected under NDPS Act; court found no total non-compliance of Section 42 NDPS and presence of prima facie material including WhatsApp chats indicating involvement
facts: Imran Ilyas Dalla was arrested during a raid conducted on 15.06.2019 for possession of Mephedrone, a psychotropic substance, along with co-accused Mujahid. The raid was conducted around 1:15 AM and resulted in recovery of contraband. The defense argued non-compliance with Section 42 NDPS Act, as the raid occurred between sunset and sunrise allegedly without proper authorization.
legal_issues: Whether alleged non-compliance with Section 42 NDPS Act regarding night raid and empowered officer invalidates the search and justifies bail.
judgment_reason: The court held that documents showed substantial compliance with Section 42 NDPS, including prior permission from superior officer. Prima facie evidence such as WhatsApp chats and statements linking the applicant to the co-accused supported continued detention. Therefore, bail was denied.
summary: Bombay High Court rejected Imran Ilyas Dalla’s bail plea in a Mephedrone case, finding sufficient procedural compliance under Section 42 NDPS and prima facie digital evidence.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 42 NDPS requires empowered officer and communication of belief within 72 hours for night raids', 'Total non-compliance renders the search illegal, but delay with justification may be permissible', 'Prima facie digital evidence can support continued detention under NDPS Act', 'Liberal bail policy is not applicable under NDPS Act as per SC in State of Kerala v. Rajesh']

case_title: Vijay vs State (NCT Of Delhi)
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after nearly 6 years in custody; court noted delay in trial and that material witnesses had been examined
facts: In 2016, a 9-month-old child was kidnapped while playing with his mother in Narela, Delhi. Accused Vijay was arrested along with seven others. As per the prosecution, the child was kidnapped by Hemant and Rakesh and passed through a series of intermediaries, eventually recovered from Vikrant Verma. Vijay's alleged involvement was based on disclosure statements indicating he met other co-accused during the chain of custody.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged pre-trial custody and completion of testimony of material witnesses justify bail in a kidnapping-for-sale case under IPC Sections 363 to 372.
judgment_reason: The court noted that only 6 of 31 witnesses had been examined despite nearly 6 years in custody. The main purchaser of the child had already been granted bail. With public witnesses already examined, risk of influence was minimal, justifying bail under fair trial considerations.
summary: Vijay was granted bail in a child kidnapping case after nearly 6 years in custody, with court citing delayed trial and completed examination of key witnesses.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Prolonged custody and delayed trial can justify bail despite serious charges', 'When public/material witnesses have been examined, risk of tampering is reduced', 'Parity applies if similarly placed co-accused have received bail']

case_title: Mr. Manjunath P vs State By Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected as the petitioner was one of the main accused in kidnapping and trafficking a child; investigation ongoing and charge sheet not filed
facts: Mr. Manjunath P was arrested on 18.04.2024 in connection with the kidnapping and trafficking of a child. The FIR was initially registered against unknown persons. During investigation, the petitioner and three co-accused were apprehended. Allegedly, the petitioner and accused No.2 kidnapped the child and took him to the residence of accused No.3. The child was subsequently rescued.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted to an accused involved in kidnapping and child trafficking when investigation is incomplete and the accused has a direct role in the offence.
judgment_reason: The court noted that the petitioner played a direct role in kidnapping the child, unlike co-accused No.3 who was granted bail. Since the investigation was ongoing and the charge sheet had not yet been filed, the court denied bail at this stage.
summary: Karnataka High Court denied bail to Manjunath P in a child kidnapping and trafficking case, citing his active role and the ongoing investigation.

case_title: Sayyed Sheru Sayyed Budan vs The State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to seizure of commercial quantity of brown sugar and sufficient compliance with Section 50 NDPS Act despite technical objections
facts: Sayyed Sheru Sayyed Budan was arrested in 2021 after being found with a red bag containing five plastic packets of brown sugar weighing 500 grams, valued at ₹7.5 lakhs, during a police raid at Hotel Residency Park. He attempted to flee but was apprehended on the spot. A prior bail application had been rejected based on the commercial quantity involved.
legal_issues: Whether non-compliance with Section 50 of the NDPS Act and absence of criminal antecedents justified bail despite commercial quantity of narcotics seized.
judgment_reason: The court found that inventory and sampling were conducted under Magistrate supervision and certified, amounting to sufficient compliance with Section 50 NDPS. Citing absence of any change in circumstance and earlier rejection on merits, the court denied the application.
summary: Bombay High Court denied bail to Sayyed Sheru Sayyed Budan for possession of 500g brown sugar, finding Section 50 NDPS Act had been complied with and no change in circumstance since earlier denial.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Compliance with Section 50 NDPS Act includes certification by Magistrate of inventory and sample collection', 'Bail not granted where commercial quantity is recovered and no change in circumstance exists', 'Courts should be cautious in granting bail for serious narcotic offences']

case_title: Bilal Changesh Khan vs Union Of India And Anr
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted due to non-compliance with Section 52A NDPS Act and prolonged incarceration without trial progress
facts: Bilal Changesh Khan was arrested in December 2020 after a co-accused, found with 5g of Mephedrone, disclosed Bilal's involvement. Bilal was then apprehended in an auto-rickshaw and found with 52g of Mephedrone. He remained in custody for over 3 years. His prior bail applications had been rejected. In this third application, he raised the issue of non-compliance with Section 52A of the NDPS Act for the first time.
legal_issues: Whether non-compliance with Section 52A NDPS Act in the sampling and certification process renders the prosecution’s case doubtful and justifies bail in a commercial quantity case.
judgment_reason: The court found that the sampling and certification process did not comply with Section 52A NDPS Act, as samples were not drawn or certified before a Magistrate. Citing binding Supreme Court precedents, the court held that such non-compliance created reasonable doubt as to the accused's guilt. Considering his clean antecedents and over 3 years of incarceration, bail was granted.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Bilal Changesh Khan due to non-compliance with Section 52A NDPS Act and prolonged pre-trial detention.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Non-compliance with Section 52A NDPS Act vitiates prosecution', 'Long incarceration without trial progress can justify bail', 'Section 37 NDPS Act rigors do not apply when statutory procedure is violated']

case_title: Praveen Kumar @ Golu vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted based on clean antecedents and co-accused with similar or graver allegations having already been granted bail
facts: A six-month-old child was kidnapped by a named accused and later recovered from the house of co-accused Vishwajit Kumar. Praveen Kumar @ Golu was not named in the FIR, but was implicated through the statement of another co-accused, Chandan Verma, who claimed Praveen connected him with Vishwajit Kumar. The prosecution alleged Praveen facilitated the kidnapping. He had no prior criminal history and had been in custody since July 2023.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused is not named in the FIR, has no prior criminal record, and co-accused with direct allegations have already been granted bail.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail due to the petitioner’s clean antecedents, indirect implication via co-accused statement, and parity with co-accused who were already granted bail. Conditions were imposed to ensure attendance and prevent interference with the trial.
summary: Praveen Kumar @ Golu was granted bail in a kidnapping case due to clean antecedents, indirect involvement, and bail granted to similarly placed co-accused.

case_title: Nanda Manjunath vs State Of Karnataka
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Anticipatory bail granted due to parity with co-accused already on bail and willingness to cooperate with investigation
facts: Nanda Manjunath was accused of kidnapping a child born from the complainant’s second marriage and taking the child to Singapore. The complainant alleged that the child was unlawfully removed from her custody. The FIR invoked kidnapping and cheating provisions. Other co-accused had already been granted bail.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail can be granted when co-accused have already been granted bail and the petitioner shows willingness to cooperate with investigation in a child custody-related kidnapping case.
judgment_reason: The court noted that other co-accused had been granted bail, and the petitioner was cooperating with the investigation. The allegations stemmed from a custodial dispute rather than a criminal conspiracy. Hence, anticipatory bail was granted with conditions.
summary: Karnataka High Court granted anticipatory bail to Nanda Manjunath in a child custody-related kidnapping case, citing parity with co-accused and cooperation with investigation.

case_title: Shafik Sattar Shah vs State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected for second time due to recovery of 40.5 kg ganja and failure to satisfy conditions under Section 37 NDPS Act despite prolonged incarceration
facts: Shafik Sattar Shah was arrested on 18 June 2020 after being intercepted in a vehicle with co-accused Gayasoddin Shaikh, found in possession of 40.5 kg of ganja. The accused were informed of their rights under Section 50 NDPS Act and samples were collected. Charge sheet was filed. Co-accused was later granted bail on technical grounds. The applicant had been in custody for over 3.5 years at the time of this second bail application.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration and alleged discrepancies in sampling and seizure justify bail in a commercial quantity NDPS case under Section 37.
judgment_reason: The court rejected the bail citing the bar under Section 37 NDPS Act, large quantity recovered, and prior rejection of bail on similar grounds. It held that the applicant’s grounds regarding sampling and possession must be examined during trial and do not override the statutory restrictions at the bail stage.
summary: Bombay High Court denied bail to Shafik Sattar Shah in a 40.5 kg ganja case, ruling that long custody and seizure discrepancies did not satisfy NDPS bail conditions.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act imposes twin conditions of non-guilt and no reoffending', 'Long incarceration alone does not override Section 37 restrictions', 'Discrepancies in seizure or sampling must be tested at trial, not at bail stage']

case_title: Smt. Mangeethadevi vs State
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected due to gravity of child kidnapping and ransom case; petitioners were non-residents and absconding co-accused remained at large
facts: Smt. Mangeethadevi and co-accused were arrested for kidnapping a child and demanding a ₹50 lakh ransom. The child was rescued based on GPS tracking and a call made by accused No.4. Investigation revealed that Mangeethadevi, a neighbor of the complainant, had shared information with the others and helped plan the kidnapping. She was arrested following a co-accused's voluntary statement. One accused remains absconding.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted to accused involved in kidnapping and ransom conspiracy when one co-accused remains absconding and the accused are not local residents.
judgment_reason: The court held that since the accused were not permanent residents, the offence was serious, and one co-accused was absconding, granting bail could jeopardize the investigation. The child had also identified the accused in a statement. Hence, bail was denied.
summary: Karnataka High Court rejected bail to Smt. Mangeethadevi in a kidnapping and ransom case, citing gravity of offence, non-residency, and risk of absconding with one co-accused still at large.

case_title: Novafor Samuel Inoamaobi vs The State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after forensic clarification that seized substances were not covered under NDPS Act; Court also ordered Rs. 2 lakh compensation for wrongful incarceration
facts: Novafor Samuel Inoamaobi, a foreign national, was arrested in October 2020 for alleged possession of cocaine and ecstasy based on substances seized in a police trap. The initial forensic report suggested NDPS Act applicability. However, a corrigendum from the Forensic Lab later clarified that the substances were Lidocaine, Tapentadol, and Caffeine—none of which fall under the NDPS Act. The court noted violation of Article 21 due to prolonged wrongful incarceration.
legal_issues: Whether continued detention was justified when subsequent forensic analysis established that seized substances did not fall within the purview of the NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The Court found that the initial basis for detention—alleged possession of narcotics—was invalidated by the corrected forensic report. Upholding Article 21 protections, it granted bail and ordered compensation of ₹2 lakhs for wrongful incarceration.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Novafor Samuel after forensic clarification showed no narcotic substances were seized, and ordered ₹2 lakh compensation for wrongful custody.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Right to life and liberty under Article 21 extends to foreign nationals', 'Wrongful incarceration based on erroneous forensic evidence warrants compensation', 'Preventive detention must adhere strictly to material accuracy and legal classification of substances']

case_title: Davinderjit Kaur @ Aman vs State Of Punjab
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after 2 years in custody; co-accused had already been granted bail and trial was progressing slowly
facts: Davinderjit Kaur @ Aman was accused of receiving a kidnapped newborn from co-accused Gurpreet Singh and Ranjit Singh. The kidnapping was allegedly planned by Kiran, a hospital sweeper, on instructions from the petitioner who was promised money by one Rekha Khanna. The child was recovered from the petitioner’s rented accommodation.
legal_issues: Whether bail can be granted when the accused is not named in the FIR, has no prior record, and co-accused have already been granted bail despite serious charges.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail citing the petitioner’s extended pre-trial detention (over 2 years), absence of other criminal involvement, recovery of the child, and parity with co-accused already granted bail.
summary: Davinderjit Kaur @ Aman was granted bail after 2 years in custody in a child kidnapping case, as co-accused had already secured bail and trial delays persisted.

case_title: Zainabi Fakir Mohammed Khan vs The State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted due to parity with co-accused, completion of investigation, and absence of independent material implicating the applicant
facts: The case involves the kidnapping of a 2.5-year-old child. It was alleged that accused Maya Kale kidnapped the child at the behest of another co-accused and handed the child to the applicant, Zainabi, who allegedly agreed to sell the child to Pooja Shettiyar for ₹70,000. Instead of cash, property documents were given. The child was eventually rescued from Pooja. Zainabi was arrested as Accused No.2 based on statements of co-accused.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when co-accused has already been released, charge sheet has been filed, and there is no independent evidence of the applicant's involvement beyond co-accused statements.
judgment_reason: The court granted bail noting that co-accused Pooja had already been granted bail, the investigation was complete, and there was no material beyond statements of co-accused to establish the applicant’s direct involvement. Delay in trial commencement was also a factor.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Zainabi Khan in a child kidnapping case due to lack of independent evidence, co-accused having received bail, and completion of investigation.

case_title: Shivam Sharma vs State Of U.P.
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted due to clean antecedents, parity with co-accused already granted bail, and hostile testimony of the informant in trial
facts: Shivam Sharma was accused along with two others of kidnapping a 14-month-old child. The child was recovered from co-accused Baby Devi, who has already been granted bail, along with another co-accused Abhishek. The first informant later turned hostile in court and did not support the prosecution case. The accused had no criminal record and had been in jail since March 2023.
legal_issues: Whether bail should be granted when co-accused with similar roles have been granted bail, and the main prosecution witness has turned hostile.
judgment_reason: The court considered the lack of criminal history, the informant turning hostile, the fact that similarly situated co-accused were granted bail, and the prolonged custody of the applicant to grant bail.
summary: Shivam Sharma was granted bail in a child kidnapping case due to clean record, parity with co-accused, and the informant turning hostile during trial.

case_title: Pravin Manilal Thakker And Anr vs The State Of Maharashtra And Anr
judge: Justice S.J. Kathawalla, Justice Surendra P. Tavade
accused_name: Parth Pravin Thakker and Pranav Hasmukh Thakker
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail rejected by Special NDPS Court, Thane; High Court writ petition sought transfer of accused sons to rehabilitation center under police protection
facts: Parth and Pranav, two highly educated young men, were allegedly influenced and manipulated by a woman posing as an astrologer. They reportedly left their homes to stay with her, fell under her influence, and began using ganja. A raid led to their arrest along with the woman under NDPS Act. Their parents sought interim bail and permission to shift them to a rehabilitation center citing low quantity (14.9 grams) and absence of prior criminal record.
legal_issues: Whether the court can grant temporary or regular bail to facilitate rehabilitation when the accused are allegedly addicted and under external influence, and when the seized quantity is below the small quantity threshold under NDPS Act.
judgment_reason: The High Court did not grant immediate bail or release but encouraged the accused to pursue their pending bail applications before the appropriate bench. It recognized the parents' concern and welfare motive but held that bail must be decided on merits by the competent judge.
summary: Bombay High Court declined to pass interim bail order for two young men arrested under NDPS Act but directed their pending bail plea be decided expeditiously; parents had sought rehabilitation.

case_title: Ramesh Sahani vs The State Of Bihar
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Anticipatory bail rejected as allegations involved kidnapping of a 2.5-year-old child and child was not yet recovered
facts: The informant alleged that his 2.5-year-old son disappeared while playing and suspected Ramesh Sahani to be involved, as he had earlier threatened the informant. The petitioner was not named directly but was suspected due to previous threats. The child had not been recovered at the time of the bail hearing.
legal_issues: Whether anticipatory bail should be granted based on suspicion without direct evidence in a kidnapping case involving a minor child who remains missing.
judgment_reason: The court held that the nature of the allegation—kidnapping of a minor child—and the fact that the child had not yet been recovered were serious grounds for rejecting anticipatory bail. The court advised that if the petitioner surrenders, the lower court may consider the bail application on merits.
summary: Patna High Court denied anticipatory bail to Ramesh Sahani in a kidnapping case involving a minor child, citing the gravity of allegations and the child’s continued disappearance.

case_title: Salman Shah Jamil Ahmed Shah vs The State Of Maharashtra
bail_outcome_label_detailed: Regular bail granted after more than 3 years in custody for non-commercial quantity of Charas and significant trial delay
facts: Salman Shah was arrested on 19 February 2018 after police recovered 900 grams of Charas from his possession during a raid near Shivaji Maidan. He was accused of intending to sell the contraband. Despite a prior withdrawal of a bail plea, he had been in custody for over three years with no progress in trial.
legal_issues: Whether prolonged incarceration for non-commercial quantity under NDPS Act justifies bail when Section 37 does not apply and the trial has not progressed.
judgment_reason: The court held that the contraband quantity was non-commercial and Section 37 NDPS Act did not apply. Given the prolonged custody of over three years and lack of trial progress despite prior directions, bail was granted.
summary: Bombay High Court granted bail to Salman Shah after over 3 years in custody for possessing non-commercial quantity of Charas, noting trial delays and non-applicability of Section 37 NDPS Act.
legal_principles_discussed: ['Section 37 NDPS Act is not attracted in non-commercial quantity cases', 'Prolonged custody and failure to conclude trial are valid grounds for bail', 'Bail can be granted even after prior rejection if circumstances materially change']

case_title: Savita W/O Ram Poul vs The State Of Maharashtra
